The morning I decided to betray my profession for something wilder than precedent, the air over Meridian tasted like warm copper and magnolia syrup. The courthouse steps sweated, and the big clock above the clerk’s office seemed to tick in lumps. Meridian has always been a town that wears its history like a suit a shade too tight. Threads show around the elbows. People pretend they don’t notice.

I’d been practicing law a decade by then, which is to say I’d learned to hold my breath while rooms filled with other people’s stenched-up grievances. I did divorces, property disputes, a few slips and falls—nothing heroic, nothing that left much of a mark except where it rubbed me thin. Outside my office window the train tracks buzzed, and the sky broke into its usual fragile blue. Clients liked to see that blue; juries liked to have it in their periphery. They were teddy-bear folk that way, needing softness somewhere even if all they got was color.

My name is Barrett, though most of Meridian still calls me Barry despite all my efforts to age into something crisper. I’m tall when I remember to stand right. Some days the cuff of my shirt will catch on a drawer and I’ll feel an unreasonable irritation, a tug, as if some stitch of me is not properly hidden. You’ll laugh; I do not. The best lawyers are the ones who distrust their own seams.

It was a Tuesday, which is the day of the week where the courthouse coffee tastes like burnt molasses and news of small disasters trickles in from every direction. I was sitting with a man named Oakes in my conference room, discussing the relative merits of keeping his father’s violin or selling it to pay down the lien on the house, when the call came from the hospital. Oakes ran his hand over the back of his neck the way you check for a price tag in a store. That habit survives even in grief.

“Go on,” he told me, after I’d tried to ignore the call twice. “You’re no good to me pretending I matter more than whatever that is.”

“This matters,” I said automatically. Then I picked up the call. It was Dr. Darla Kettering, the oncologist I’d met pro bono at one of those grim do-gooder panels lawyers sit on to feel less like barnacles.

“Mr. Barrett,” she said, skipping my last name because the speaker phone in her office always made mine sound like I’d made it up. “Do you have a minute today or are you in trial?”

“I’ve got a client in the room,” I said. “But I can call you back.”

“It’s about your mother,” she said, and that cut the air sideways and left me with a ridiculous sweet taste in my mouth, what you taste when cotton gets wet. It had been four years since my mother died, and still that word could pull the room like a rug, drag everything toward its center.

“Give me an hour,” I said.

“I’ll hold lunch,” she replied. “You won’t want to rush this.”

After I walked Oakes to his truck and told him to keep the violin no matter what anyone else suggested—some objects hold a person-shaped space no court can measure—I drove out to Saint Rose. The hospital’s new wing still had that fresh paint smell that made my nose itch, clean and artificial, like talc sprinkled too thick in a child’s dresser. In the elevator, I could hear my pulse pattering like someone tapping a loose button on a table. The metal walls threw my reflection back at me with a wobble. I rubbed my thumb over my wrist bone. I stopped. The doors slid open.

Darla met me in the hallway and hugged me like we’d already shared something heavy and rough. She was short, with steady, quick eyes and a laugh that could talk anyone off a ledge if she timed it right. She ushered me into her office, where the books looked like they had plastic covers on them that my eye couldn’t quite focus on. For a moment, I thought of my mother’s sewing basket, the tiny jars of buttons and the strawberry-shaped pincushion heavy with metal.

“You told me you didn’t want to be updated on her file,” Darla began gently. “I know that. But I found something in relation to another patient.”

“Found something.” My voice came out more like an accusation than the question I intended. Lawyers adopt their tones like borrowed suits.

“We keep the data,” she said. “We all vote to. It’s anonymized. But you made me curious, Barrett. The way you said—at the funeral—that you were sorry you didn’t understand earlier what kind of thing took her. It stuck with me. Probably not fair. Anyway, this is me being unfair. Sit down.”

I sat. She pushed a thin folder toward me, paper clip holding pages in that brutal tight way, a little tension you can feel through your nails.

“My patient’s name is Tinsley,” she said. “She didn’t respond to standard chemo. I wanted to try off-label something with her, and I compared her markers to archived cases. Your mother’s profile is—was—similar. They had a particular damaged loop on chromosome 17. You don’t care about the number. Point is, a drug used for a completely different disease lights up that segment.”

“Lights up as in cures?” I said, trying not to lean too far toward the nonsense of hope.

“Lights up as in arrests cell lines in vitro, yes,” she said. “In patients, we have complications. Immune stuff. But listen to me. There’s one more twist. Your mother was given a routine antibiotic near the end when she got an infection. Her white count did something weirder than any white count I have seen. For forty-eight hours, her blast cells stopped replicating.”

I heard this like you hear the phrase, “I found a door,” in a house where you’d lived for years and never looked behind a piece of furniture. “Did anyone notice?”

“Not at the time,” she said. “She was too ill. She had too many other processes failing. I’m sorry.”

“And this other patient? Tinsley?”

“I dosed her with an antibiotic last week,” Darla said. “She is stable. This is not supposed to work like this. But there is perhaps a synergy. I’ll say the ugly word: cure. Or cure-adjacent. I know I am stepping out of the lines telling you. But I’m telling you because you strike me as the kind of person who doesn’t like lines when they’re arbitrary.”

I stared down at the photocopies, the graphs like low mountains, the months spread in numeric digits. The letters of the antibiotic’s name looked like something I’d seen scrawled on a napkin or a prescription bottle in a joke. The name was old-fashioned and sweet. I thought of my mother muttering to herself over her quilting, the way she’d tug fabric and iron it and then, hold it up to my chest as if measuring something only she understood.

“If this is real,” I said. “If this is anything other than a fluke—”

“It can’t be just ours,” she said quickly. “It would need to be tested, shared, repeated. I brought it to the board. They… we. They want to wait. There are liability issues. There is the possibility of false hope. There is the hospital’s relationship with donors whose children died. It’s complicated.”

In the stillness after that word I heard a deep sound like a low cello under the normal beep of the hall monitors. Meridian likes everything to be simple or at least pretend simple. Complicated gets you called arrogant.

“You want me to sue your hospital into giving your patient an antibiotic I can get at a CVS?” I said. It came out ugly because I needed someone to be angry at.

“No,” she said. “I want you to talk to Tinsley’s family. To explain the risk. To give me cover to do what I already did.”

“You already did,” I said.

“Twice,” she said, and there was a little smile at the edge of her mouth. “Don’t you find it strange that an oncologist has to ask a lawyer to help her be brave?”

It was then, thinking of bravery like an object we could both hold, that I felt something else happen. A looseness in my chest, like a seam let out. I could tell you I became a different man in that second, but it’s more accurate to say I started telling a different story about myself. Lawyers are trained story-tellers. Cancer is a story people choke on; we smooth our throats and try again.

“I’ll do it,” I said. “Tell me about the family.”

The Tinsleys turned out to be from the north end of the county, a place of red clay and neighborhoods stacked in with more care than their builders had money for. Their daughter was named Joy, which seemed either bold or cruel, depending on how cynical you were that day. She had hair like unlucky wheat and eyes that made you check to see if your own pupils worked.

Joy listened to me like she’d been practicing for it. Her father, Earl, sat in silence, a demolished man with hands like paddles. Her mother wore a scarf with cartoon oranges on it and kept folding it like there was a right way she might eventually arrive at if she just respected the fabric. When I told them what Darla suspected, a kind of bird-wary hope skittered through the room. Later, when I would talk on the news, people would write that my voice carried “inappropriate enthusiasm.” But in a small room, with a girl holding a cup of melt-water and trying to decide whether to risk a drug that might kill her, enthusiasm is not a sin. It is the only thing that doesn’t feel like betrayal.

“I don’t want to die,” Joy said to me simply, and I put my hands on the table because sometimes you have to keep them where you can see them.

“You might not have to,” I said. “Not this month. Maybe not this year.”

“You’re just a lawyer,” Earl blurted. Then closed his eyes, ashamed, his lower lip trembling like a seam pulling tight. “I’m sorry. I’m sorry.”

“Sorry is a spell that works on fabric,” my mother used to say when she ripped out stitches. “It relaxes the thread.” I looked at Joy, then at Darla. “Your daughter will sign the consent. I will co-sign my name as a witness. The hospital can do what it needs to do with its fears.”

It should have been enough. In another town, in another lifetime, it might have been. But Meridian has its kings, and men like me are not supposed to crown anybody. That afternoon, I got my first phone call from the district attorney’s office.

“Mr. Barrett,” said the voice like ice water. “Do you remember me?”

Of course I remembered him. Sloan Greaves and I had battled over small matters for years: a petty fraud my client had not committed, a brawl in a parking lot where I’d argued the merits of a bruised nose, the politics of a case the newspaper thought smelled good and I thought smelled like smoke from wet cloth. Sloan had an angular face and the kind of hair people in Protestant churches admire, because it looks like it would never betray him and fall in his eyes at the wrong time. We were civil the way two men can be who want to be seen being civil, but we were not friends. In law school, he’d been the golden boy who could recite twenty cases and their holdings without blinking. I, by contrast, once forgot the name of the judge in open court and called him “Your Honor Sir.”

“Assistant District Attorney Greaves,” I said, because he always preferred the full title, perhaps because it sounded like he was one crowded heartbeat away from the main chair. “How can I serve the People this afternoon?”

“We’ve had a complaint,” he said. “A doctor practicing outside accepted protocols. Colluding with a plaintiff’s attorney to deprive the hospital of its shield of reasonableness.”

“You’ve been reading from the tort book,” I said. “It’s not my best genre.”

“Not reading. Remembering,” he said, and I could hear his smile rubbing the receiver. “There are also the matters of marketing claims. I hear you’re about to call a press conference. Unwise.”

“I’m about to sign a consent form for a patient you and I will never meet,” I said. “I’m about to drive across town and hold a hand.”

“I’m about to file a motion,” he said. “It will seek to enjoin the hospital from deviating from standard of care without approval of the board. It will name you in the narrative. It will—”

“You can’t enjoin hope,” I said. The line was too dramatic, and I hated myself for it. He sighed like I’d missed an easy layup.

“You can, in fact, enjoin acts,” he said. “You can enjoin a person from taking steps dangerous to the public. And you can bury your reputation in papers so thick your wrists ache holding them.”

“Is that you being afraid for me, Sloan?” I asked, because one of us had to say his name and I wanted to be the one to move us out of formalities.

“It’s me being afraid for the town,” he said. “You don’t know what you’re stirring up, Barry. Meridian looks quiet until it isn’t.”

After we hung up, I sat at my desk and looked at my hands again. You do it when you’re nervous; you take inventory. A tiny burr of fabric clung to my knuckle. I pinched it off. Once, when I was a boy, a seam burst on my favorite bear. My mother took me gently by the wrist, sat me down at the kitchen table, and took out a needle. “Hold still,” she said. “We’ll keep what’s inside inside.”

Memory is cruel; it will hurl you face-first into a simple domestic scene and then shove you, suddenly, into a fluorescent hallway where everything smells like disinfectant and fear. I stood up. I went back to Saint Rose. People in scrubs were moving like lightning disguised as people.

Joy took the antibiotic. She did not die. Her numbers slid toward normal the way a needle glides into a comfortable groove. Darla gripped my shoulder once, in the hall, so hard I saw stars, her fingers digging like she had found the little stiff patches of my coat and wanted to test them for structure. “We need to be careful,” she whispered, and I nodded because I knew she meant more than medicine.

When the story came out—as of course it had to—it came out not because I called a press conference, but because Meridian loves a secret so much it will run into the street and scream its lungs out to keep the pressure down. A cousin told an aunt who told a pastor who told a barber who told a speech therapist. By morning, the mailbox of my office had comments like confetti. People brought pies. People brought sharp questions. People brought the kind of low, ugly whispers a small place feeds on when it’s hungry.

“You think you found a cure?” asked a man in a hardware store, leaning across the counter until he fogged the plexiglass with his breath. “You really think God likes you that much?”

“I think we learned something,” I said, trying to be mild. He shoved a box of screws toward me harder than necessary, then smiled like we were friends again. I paid. I walked to my truck. The sun hit the hood so hard I thought it might melt me and pour me down into the street like syrup.

If I had known what was coming, would I have done it differently? I sometimes tell myself I would have kept to the shadows longer. But that’s a lie. The second week, we found two more patients whose charts winked at Darla’s hunch. The antibiotic—ordinary, cheap—paired with a generic cancer drug, was doing something unlicensed and gleeful in their blood. The third week, a nurse emailed me anonymously to say she believed her brother had the same markers. The email had typos and a little heart at the end, like she couldn’t decide if she was being a scientist or a friend.

Then the board suspended Darla’s privileges.

It happened in a room with glass walls and a long table and a jug of water with lemon and mint leaves floating like drowned ornaments. I stood at one end, in a jacket that felt too new, the weave too obvious. Darla stood at the other end. The chairman of the board, a man named Olan McCreedy whose family owned half the banks and all the respect, neatly arranged his notes like he was dealing cards in a game he knew he would win.

“You have put us in a difficult position, Doctor Kettering,” he said. “This hospital cannot be a laboratory.”

“This town dies when we pretend it is not,” she said, without heat. “People die all the time while we protect our own.”

“You’re unrepentant,” said McCreedy, softly, as if he were noting the weather.

“I’m right,” she said.

They voted. The motion carried. She lost her keys. She lost the access a doctor needs to do what she knows how to do.

When we came outside, the sky had gone that bruised color it gets before a thunderstorm, yellowish at the edges, like an old book that’s been thumbed too much. Darla laughed to keep her face from breaking.

“Now what?” I asked.

“Now you do what you do,” she said. “Now you file something.”

I did. I filed with anger and with care. I wrote so meticulously my fingers cramped and the pads of them felt hot. My sentences had sharp openings and easy landings. I filed asking the court to require the hospital to adopt as emergency protocol what we had seen in three patients in Meridian and another two at a clinic Darla had whispered to in Alabama. I pulled every string I knew. I wrote like a man who could sew with paper.

“They’ll come for you first,” warned my friend Pil, who worked at the radio station and knew where the stories in town hid and how often they fed. “It’ll be rough.”

He was right. The merchants stopped smiling when I walked by. Letters to the editor spelled my name in creative ways. A cartoon appeared with my head on a bottle of snake oil. A man in a truck rolled down his window outside the courthouse and shouted, “Barrett, you’re a danger to people who love their families,” and then, seeing my face, added in an embarrassed voice, “No offense.”

Sloan filed his motion to enjoin. He wore a tie the color of money and a look like he had eaten something too rich and couldn’t let himself burp because it would look common. In the hearing, he delivered his lines with ease. The judge liked him. The judge’s grand-niece had married his cousin, and that counted for something even if we all pretended the court did not notice such little stitches connecting things.

“Mr. Greaves is asking this court to do the opposite of what he claims,” I told the judge when it was my turn. “He wants to turn the standard of care into a padlock, when it was meant to be a belt. He wants to strap us so tight we can’t breathe. And my client”—I gestured toward Joy, who sat in the back row with a scarf on her head, smiling at something Darla had said under her breath—“just wants to live a little more.”

“Counsel,” said the judge, half-exasperated, half-pleased at the theater. “Do not manipulate the gallery.”

“I wouldn’t dream of it,” I said, and then I dreamt of it that night, very vividly.

The court delayed. The town talked. The newspaper could not decide if I was a savior or a salesman. A vigil appeared on the courthouse lawn, candles in paper cups glowing at the bases of the benches, notes tucked under stones with names written in earnest block letters. One morning, as if Meridian decided at last that my fate should be decided by a coin toss, the Post Office declared it would hold a forum for all “interested parties” on “the issue of non-standard medical propaganda.” The Post Office is where you go in Meridian to buy stamps, mail grievance, and announce your intention to serve society. We gathered there on a Wednesday between the hours of two and four, under fluorescent bulbs that hum in a way that makes your teeth feel slightly looser than you would prefer.

Sloan stood up first and spoke like a hymn. He had been captain of the debate team in high school and, it is said, dated the prettiest girl in the county for a while, long enough to make her parents believe he could be part of their lineage. He told us all about safety, about process, about law as a way to equalize luck and not the opposite. People nodded. He said the word “reckless” like it was a personal insult to him, and three women made the same face at the same time in the front row, a kind of flinch you only get when you are frightened and attracted at once.

When it was my turn, I began in a voice too soft for a room that size. It was all wrong. I could feel the thread slipping in my hands. Pil motioned from the back to project. Darla put her hands over her eyes for a second, then took them away like she was unseeing the person she saw me turning into. Joy sat next to her, and her smile never faltered, even when I fumbled the statistics, even when I said “chromosome 7” and then had to correct it to 17 and someone tittered like a child in church who had been told not to laugh.

“Forgive me,” I said finally, abandoning whatever script I had been trying to knit. “I am not a scientist. I am a man who watched his mother’s mouth go slack in a hospital and never quite recovered. I am someone who sees in the law not a glass shield but a mesh. It keeps out the big things and lets the air through. I want us to be able to breathe. Maybe you think I’m the wrong person to ask you to trust this. Maybe I’m the right one.”

It wasn’t a great speech, but it was mine, and Meridian does have a fondness for authenticity, which it mistakes for art all the time. The room softened. People began to look at me like I was something alive and not just a cautionary tale.

“I know you,” said a voice then, and I turned. An old man I’d defended on a traffic ticket eight years ago stood up, his suspenders tight on his shoulders. “You kept me from losing my license. I drive my wife to church every Sunday. Don’t let them tell you not to help folks. You help folks.”

That was when Sloan did something he’d never done in a public room before: he let his energy drop. He looked tired. He leaned against the wall like he couldn’t quite feel his edges. He has a scar on his wrist most people don’t notice; I noticed it now. He caught my eye and then, before anyone else could, he turned to the side, and I swear to you, he hummed—just a fraction of a tune, aimless at first and then resolving, as if he were finding a melody.

“Enough,” said the Postmaster, because the clock on the wall had reached four and his power is absolute when it comes to closing time. “No more statements. We have heard our community.”

We filed out. The sun had lowered and the heat felt less like a punishment and more like the tail end of some mercy. I looked for Darla. She had a habit of vanishing when she had to cry; I suspected she’d stolen away to the alley to compose herself. Sloan came up beside me silently, so close I could smell the starch in his shirt and a faint, unexpected scent of cedar.

“I need to talk to you,” he said. “Not here.”

“Too many witnesses?” I asked, unable to resist.

“Too much noise,” he said. “There’s music under this we’re not hearing.”

“You going to sing it out for me?” I said, and meant it as a joke. He didn’t smile.

His office lives in a building that used to be a hat store. The ceiling is high and heavy and the light wired and old. He unlocked the door. Inside, it is quieter than any other place in Meridian, as if the building took its promise of secrecy seriously. He went to his desk and opened a drawer. He took out something I did not recognize at first—sheet music. Blank measures printed lightly, and a pencil with a chewed-up eraser, and a small black metronome that ticked even when you didn’t wind it if the air conditioner blew right on it.

“You play?” I said, surprised at how personal the question felt, and how sloppily it fell out of my mouth.

“No,” he said. “I used to write. We all have something we used to do, yes?”

“Yes,” I said, thinking of how I used to sleep.

“My father wanted me to win,” he said. “Music isn’t a winning thing in Meridian. It’s a quiet thing. Quiet things get eaten.”

I waited for the but. It didn’t arrive. He sat down, then stood immediately, then sat again like a man who had never learned what his body preferred. He looked at me carefully, as if reading notes on a page and trying to hear the chord.

“You think you’ve found a way to cure cancer,” he said.

“I think Darla did,” I said. “You can call it an algorithm if you want. It’s big and small at once. It’s a combination of old things in a new way. It’s sewing pieces that didn’t look like they belonged.”

He nodded, impatient at himself. He drummed his fingers once on the wooden desk.

“I can let you keep going,” he said. “Or I can stop you cold.”

“That’s—” I began, but he raised his hand.

“I can’t do either alone,” he said. “I am not the judge. But I can orchestrate. I can make the song that plays in the judge’s ear or the board’s ear. You know this. You resent it.” He closed his eyes for a moment and said, almost too softly to hear, “I don’t want to be that man anymore.”

It was my turn to be silent. He kept his eyes closed like a person about to leap.

“I wake up,” he said. “And all I see are measures. Four by four. Six by eight. Things that can hold sound. But I put words in them instead of notes, and they cut people. I’m tired, Barrett. My son—did you know I had a son?—he sits on the carpet and bangs on a toy piano with his palms and shrieks with joy, real joy, not the kind our Joy plays at for our sakes, and I think, why would I not want to be as close to that as possible with whatever time I get.”

“You’re leaving?” I asked, and hated how hungry I sounded.

“I don’t know,” he said. “But I’m moving.”

He looked scared of the confession. He looked like the first time I’d seen one of Joy’s numbers move toward the unthinkable. Beautiful. Dangerous. I should have said something. Thank you, perhaps. Or I’m sorry. Or Let me help. Instead, I stared stupidly at the pencil and the metronome and at his hands, wondering at the long, narrow fingers, the nails unbelievably neat, the cuticles trimmed just so, the ridges like the faintest stitched line from thumb to forefinger where the skin should be thicker and is not.

“My wife says it’s a midlife crisis,” he said. “I told her crises are for the young. The old have transformations.”

“You’re not old,” I said.

“I feel very old,” he said. He smiled then, finally, a smile that felt like something unpinned inside him and fell to the floor softly. “I don’t expect you to forgive me for everything I’ve done. But I want you to hear one more thing. There are people in this town with a stake you have not yet met. Men whose shirts smell like warehouses and the inside of new cars. They like things the way they are. They like their stories quiet, and their little risks compartmentalized and their dividends predictable. They will hurt you. I don’t know how. They’ll figure out a way that doesn’t look unseemly.”

“Thank you,” I said, truly. The words landed between us like a square of fabric, and we both looked at it like we were trying to decide what to make out of it.

I left his office and the evening felt more like a corridor than a sky. The whole town a hallway, the streetlights little stitches tacked along the edges. My phone vibrated. A text from Darla: they had tapped her home phone, she thought, because someone had called asking specific questions about Tinsley’s dosage; she had called the number back and got only a recorded voice. I told her to come to my office. I told her to bring Joy if she could.

They came together, mother and daughter and doctor and fear, and we sat in my conference room with the ceiling fan clicking slightly on one blade—click at each turn, click like a metronome misaligned. Joy fell asleep in the chair with her hands folded in her lap, palms up, fingers loose like she was holding air.

“I don’t know how to do this,” Darla said, a confession so childlike I loved her for it. “It’s like I was taught one story and then, mid-way, someone told me there was a better plot and I had to begin again without losing my place.”

“You’re doing it,” I said. “That’s how it feels.”

She nodded. “I’ve been talking to a lab in Jackson that can culture the cell lines and run this faster. If we move it out of Meridian for the beat, it’s less—visible.” She said the word like it was damp cloth. “We might lose equity.”

“Nothing about this is equitable,” I said.

We were quiet. The town hummed around us, a thing with a thousand stitched mouths. Outside, a train passed, its horn drawn out and slow. Joy stirred and murmured something I didn’t catch, then slept deeper, her head falling to the side, an angle that would have hurt me; she looked comfortable.

I admired her scarf. It was a pattern of little gold stars and something else I could not name. I went closer and then felt rude and stepped back. I have a terrible urge to touch fabric when I see it, to feel the grain, to note the thickness. My mother could tell, even on days when I swore I was being discreet. “Hands that crave cloth,” she would tease, her needle flashing in the kitchen lamplight. “You’ll be a tailor.” I became a lawyer. Which is a kind of tailor. My suits have always been a fraction too sharp at the shoulders, so I remember they’re on my body.

At midnight, after they’d gone, I stood in the doorway of my office and listened to the cicadas perform their simple, arrogant symphony. I thought of Sloan at his desk with an empty staff and a pencil, of the DA’s office, of his reputation like a gold frame around a painting that might be empty. I thought of men in rooms with glass walls, their voices smooth as oiled wood. I thought of my mother’s hands. The world was a garment and somebody had to do the repairs.

On my walk home, the streetlights haloed in the wet air, I passed E.J.’s 24-hour and saw, through the window, a little boy hugging a bear so worn its fur was almost matte, its plush flattened into a dense patience. I stopped. I don’t know why. The boy pressed his nose into the bear’s head, and his eyes closed, and his small mouth made a shape that was not quite a smile and not quite a prayer.

I went to sleep with my phone on the pillow, a thing I advise none of my clients to do. Around three in the morning, I woke with a start, certain someone had said my name. Only the air conditioner. Only the fans spinning, threads of air in a dark room. I got up, walked to the kitchen, poured water with an unsteady hand. I caught sight of myself in the reflection of the window. Even in the smudged glass, I could see exhaustion had tucked itself into the corners of my eyes. I rubbed them and felt a small roughness under the skin, like felt. I startled, hissed, laughed at myself. Weirdness visits at three a.m. like a cat that knows which house will get up to feed it.

In the morning there was an envelope under my door. No stamp. Thick, off-white, like a formal invitation had been repurposed for something less charming. Inside, a single page: if you do not stop we will open you. The letters were cut from a magazine from the seventies or maybe someone with a sense of theater had sought such. I ran my thumb along the edge of the paper and got a sensation like you get when you snag on a tag and it pulls where there is no skin to pull. It was a good threat. Efficient. The grinning cruelty of a child with scissors.

I brought Darla the note. I brought Sloan an image of it. I brought my fear to the mirror and looked at it until it looked back like an old friend. Then I put on my jacket and stood straight in it, and I drove to see Joy with a bouquet of something not too sweet, daises maybe, because lilies have too much funeral in them and roses are for apologies we cannot afford.

“You always bring the wrong flowers,” Joy teased when I knocked, and I felt myself turn into the person Meridian claimed I was. “It’s OK. I like wrong.”

On the way back to the truck, a man leaned against the hood and smiled into my face. His teeth were too straight; his shirt had a sheen to it I recognized from catalogues where the fabric is described with untrue, hopeful adjectives. Behind him stood two other men, their hands folded neatly in front as if they had been practicing docility and could turn it off if asked. The smiling man tapped my fender lightly with his knuckles, a gesture that says, We know how to make noise, and also, We can be quiet.

“We like order,” he said without introducing himself. “We like it when doctors wait their turn. We like it when lawyers do not make themselves prophets. You should go on a vacation, Barry—I can call you Barry, right?—and when you return, this will all be over, one way or another.”

“Meridian is the size of a hand,” I said, before I could stop myself. “You can’t take a vacation from your own fingers.”

“I can cut them off,” he said pleasantly, and his friends laughed as if he’d told a droll joke in the car ride over and they were delighted to hear it again. “Don’t bring the DA into this. He’s going through something delicate and musical.”

The way he said musical held contempt and disbelief and a pinch of curiosity, like music was a rumor he couldn’t quite squash. The three men stepped away in unison, like a little dance. They left without saying good-bye, and I stood there in the sun, my shadow a piece of punctuation on the pavement, wondering if I had time to become a better sort of brave.

That night, Sloan called me and didn’t speak for ten seconds. Then, faintly, like he was in another house and didn’t want to wake anyone, he said, “I wrote something.”

“A brief?” I asked.

“A song,” he said. “It’s not good yet. But it moved air in the room. I thought you should know.”

“I’m glad,” I said, and I did not know whether I meant I was glad for him, for me, or for the air.

“Don’t go anywhere,” he said. “I think the town will try to close us. There are ways to stay open. I’m learning them. They’re not in the books.”

Before I could answer, he hung up. I sat there with the phone pulling heat from my palm, amazed at the sudden, wrong-turn feeling of it all, at how the map now included places we had pretended were not in our county. My chest ached with a small, familiar pain. I pressed my fist against it and felt my body complain. At the table, the stack of pleadings I’d planned to finish had slipped slightly, the edges misaligned. I straightened them, glided my palm over until they clicked into a perfect rectangle, then left them crooked on purpose. It looked like life.

In the morning, a letter from a small clinic in Jackson sat waiting in my email. They wanted to see our data. They wanted to try the protocol. They had found two patients with fourteen matching markers. They sent me a spreadsheet so beautifully arranged I felt a childish wish to touch it, to smooth it as if smoothing could carry over to the cells in those bodies. I wrote back yes. I wrote back we are with you. I wrote back Sorry for any delay in my response, I was standing in the kitchen trying to figure out if bravery is a pantry item you can run out of.

On the refrigerator, a magnet held a photograph of my mother next to me at a fair, both of us sticky with candy, her hand on my head like she wanted to be sure it was still there. The edge of the photo had begun to curl. I pressed it flat. “We’re doing it,” I told her. On the street outside, a truck downshifted with a noise like ripping. The morning after the Jackson email, Meridian wore a sky so clean it felt like a deception. It had rained in the night—hard, vertical rain that made the magnolia leaves shine like they’d been lacquered by a feverish artisan—and now everything looked scrubbed, as if the town had been reminded it has a face and decided to wash. I shaved and nicked myself because my hand wandered thinking of other kinds of edges, then pressed toilet paper to the dot of blood like a man attempting first aid on a painting. In the window, the reflection of my jawline went in and out with the clouds. I wanted to call someone about how beautiful it all was and then remembered beauty only makes sense to people who already share your ridiculous faith in it.

Pil called first anyway, and he never bothered with preambles unless he wanted something big. He spoke in a whisper because his station manager, whom he did not respect but did not wish to offend, believed whispers signaled important news and Pil liked to make him feel included. He said the Jackson clinic wanted me on-air to talk about “community-sourced innovation,” which is a phrase I distrust and a concept I was beginning to live inside of whether or not I liked what the walls were made of. I told him no, then yes, then I said give me an hour and I’d drive over to Saint Rose to see Joy first and he could catch me on the way back if the station’s personas required me to sound like I hadn’t rehearsed.

“Say less science,” Pil advised, and then coughed. “Say more mother.”

“The town already knows mine better than I do,” I said, but he was right and we both knew it. He makes a decent living reminding people of the stories they already repeated to themselves before bed.

Darla met me at the back entrance because her badge no longer opened the side doors and she refused to be escorted by a guard who used to bring her cupcakes from his wife on Fridays. She wore her white coat over a blue dress that was too nice for what it would see that day, and she’d pinned her hair back tight, the kind of aggressive practicality women are forced to choose when they’re worried a wrong curl will be mistaken for frivolity. She kissed me on the cheek without warning, the quick brush of someone who has forgotten certain proprieties in favor of others, and then apologized as if the law forbade affection between co-conspirators.

“I slept for an hour and a half,” she said cheerfully, which is how the bravest people I know tell you they are very, very tired. “Joy’s numbers stayed—” She stopped herself from saying good. Superstition expands to fit any space it’s offered. “They stayed.”

“Your home phone?” I asked, and she nodded, her mouth flattening.

“Tapped, or else I’ve learned to be paranoid late. Doesn’t matter. We move anyway,” she said. “I talked to Dr. Carrow at Jackson. She’s got a room. She will not put us on paper until she sees it with her own eyes, and I respect her for that and I hate it because my patience is a thimble, not a bowl.”

“Dr. Carrow,” I repeated, liking the shape of the name, the way it sounded like something that carried you. “She the kind to share credit?”

“She’s the kind who doesn’t notice credit until she stumbles over it and bruises,” Darla said. “I envy people like that. My envy is not large. It’s a tidy thing.”

We laughed because we had to. In Joy’s room, light splayed itself on the floor as if wanting to nap. She had a book open face-down on her stomach like a small, sunning animal, and when she woke to see us it was with that unstartled blink only children and monks have mastered. Her scarf today had tiny birds stitched along the edge, each one bent toward the same direction, as if obeying a wind their cloth could remember.

“You look like trouble,” she told me, and I bowed slightly, because the only compliment I have ever been any good at accepting is that I am likely to make a mess.

“We’re driving to Jackson, not to run away but to be seen,” I said. “Do you think your parents can be convinced to let you nap in a moving car without believing that’s a metaphor for death?”

She grinned. “You’re the one who talks about metaphors. They talk about how far it is and whether we have to stop to pee. I have charts in my head. They have distances in miles.”

Earl and his wife arrived with a tote bag that had been a tote for bread at one time—you could tell by the faint scent no laundering could erase—and we loaded the car like we were going to the beach and not to a place where people watch numbers like hawks. Darla got behind the wheel, which surprised me and then did not, because she hates being a passenger whenever the road feels like a sentence you can finish with a good verb.

The highway between Meridian and Jackson goes past the kind of fields you think are empty until you look and see the low muscles of creatures moving through them. Kudzu tries to take whole trees into its mouth and fails prettily. Pil called once, then again, and I told him to put me on live because if I had time to think I would stop breathing. He introduced me with a song, some throwback soul number that made my ribs loosen, and said, “Meridian, you know this man, and if you don’t, you will, and he will make you mad and he will make you proud, and then you’ll want to feed him casseroles, which he accepts in tinfoil only because he trusts no one to return a Pyrex unchipped.”

It is possible to love a friend for how well he lies on your behalf. I talked for three minutes with my voice pitched low. I avoided numbers. I told a story about watching my mother fall asleep mid-needle, the thread half-pulled through the fabric, and how when I woke she had gotten up quietly and finished the seam so that in the morning the quilt looked inevitable, and how inevitability is just the name we give to stubborn kindness. The switchboard lit red, Pil later told me, with people who felt either blessed or betrayed by me, and which one you feel has a lot to do with what you ate for breakfast, or how close you’ve been standing to machines that hiss.

In Jackson, the hospital does not pretend to be anything but what it is: a space where bodies are counted against their wishes. Dr. Carrow had hair the color of a penny left on the sill for exactly one winter and eyes that didn’t scan the way doctors’ eyes sometimes do when they’re collecting you for later. She took Joy’s hand, and the way she held it without squeezing made me want to propose to her on Darla’s behalf. In the lab, the air had that metallic chill that suggests the thermometer is the one person in the room whose taste matters. Carrow walked us past things that hummed and shone with their own certainty.

“Markers match,” she said, using the flat voice of someone who has learned that good news, spoken with too much warmth, will be punished by a bad god. “We’ll draw and we’ll start. I’m going to call this an observation. It will not be nothing. You will try to understand that this very careful scene we are acting in is also theater.”

“Everything is theater,” I said, then winced because I had stolen a line from an undergraduate course I once took and barely passed.

In the room where they would hang the drug and the not-a-drug, Darla stood in the corner like she was bad at being told to be anywhere but the middle. Joy looked at us and then looked up and said, “Will my hair come back different,” which was not the question any of us expected and all of us cherished.

“It often does,” Carrow said. “Sometimes curlier. Sometimes like it won a small argument about itself. My friend’s came back with a stupid cowlick and she says the cowlick makes her brave because it refuses to obey even when prudence suggests otherwise.”

“Then good,” said Joy, and closed her eyes like a girl folding herself up, then opening on cue.

We were there for an hour before Meridian decided it could not bear to be only a place in our rearview mirror and called anyway. The board had drafted a letter to the state health department requesting an investigation into “irregularities of care.” They had copied Sloan, who called me not to gloat and not to warn, but to say a sentence without verbs. “They touched the wrong door,” he said, and I heard the exhausted gladness of a man who has finally decided to put down a heavy object he had been carrying because his father told him it made him taller.

“What door?” I asked, not because I didn’t know, but to make him say it aloud.

“Oversight,” he said. “You said it at the forum. They took the word standard and tried to turn it into something sharp. The administrator at the department? She lost her sister at twenty-six because a hospital waited. They have done themselves an injury and I cannot politely point it out, so I am calling you so you will hit it with a hammer.”

I thanked him, and then didn’t, because we’d become the kind of people with a ledger of compliments we owed and we were never going to settle the account in full. Carrow poked her head in, and Darla’s face loosened into a precise joy I have seen on very particular days—weddings that were not mistakes, verdicts that undid a year of someone else’s cruelty, mornings when rain holds off just long enough for a funeral with folding chairs.

“Look,” she said, and I did, and there it was: a graph writing a story it had refused to tell all those who came to listen before.

I did not cry because I am bad at crying when other people are brave. I reserve my tears for laundry rooms and for the exact moment I trip over a low shoe I placed in the hallway myself. Earl made a noise like the lowest note on a fat wooden instrument, and his wife pressed both her hands to her scarf with the oranges, then did a little bounce that would have been mistaken for silly in another room but was exactly right in this one. I thought of my mother’s hand on the back of my neck when I slept and woke to find nap marks on my face that she never mentioned except with a smile.

On the drive back, Meridian looked darker, either because a storm thought about arriving and declined like a guest with an excuse, or because my eyes had grown tired with all the looking. We took the road that skirts a junkyard I have always loved for its honesty. Cars sit there with their mouths open, waiting to be cannibalized, their wires like veins. Somebody had strung a piece of fabric across the chain-link fence, a flag with no nation, and it flapped with the kind of conviction you admire in fools.

The office smelled faintly of lemon because my secretary, Aimee, cleans her countertop when she is anxious, and the smell lifts through our cheap vents like republics do, unevenly, catching in the pockets and making them lemon-er than their neighbors. There was a box on my chair labeled with my name in a handwriting I did not recognize but felt I ought to. I picked it up the way you pick up a child who does not yet trust you and may kick.

Inside lay a teddy bear, not new. The fur was rubbed in patches the way fur gets rubbed when it has done its duty protecting a small person from loud clocks and grown-up laughter. A seam ran along its belly, and the seam had been cut open cleanly—no raggedness, no haste—and then tugged apart, leaving its stuffing slightly visible, a little throat on the wrong part of a body. There was a note tucked so carefully under the arm that I had to admire the hand that placed it even while wishing the hand belonged in a trap.

Do you keep what’s inside inside? it asked, without capitalization, without punctuation, as if those were luxuries we could dispense with now. A lumpy stitch closed the rest of the page, a child’s performance of mending written in thread. I put my fingers into the bear’s belly, then stopped because I am not the man who does that, and then did it anyway because maybe I am. Inside, someone had tucked a single business card. The card smelled faintly of smoke, and the name on it belonged to a warehouse company out by the highway, one that services hospitals, one owned, as it happened, by a McCreedy cousin whose wedding, I remembered, I had once attended in a suit that did not quite fit because Aimee had convinced me the photograph would live forever.

“They’re bold,” Aimee said quietly, having watched my face do what it does. “They want to be credited for the threat. That’s the part that’s always seemed strangest to me about this place. People sin and then they monogram it.”

She and I boxed the bear back up, then took it out, then boxed it again. I called Sloan and told him I would be sending a copy of the card to someone who would know what to do with it, and he said to use an envelope without a return address because theatre had to be played in all directions for this one to land. I told him he was becoming exhausting in his good advice and he said, softly, almost laughing, “You make me brave. I forgot how to be embarrassed when I stopped making music.”

That afternoon, we had our first home visit request from someone who lived an hour past where the maps give up. The email contained its own accent. It asked us to come look at a man named Buckley who had grown up with so many sisters he never learned to keep his elbows to himself and had recently been taught the limits of bone. The markers, scribbled numerically as if from memory, matched too closely to be coincidence. Darla read the note and then set her jaw and looked at me like an artist finds a subject by accident and must pretend it was an intention all along.

“If they take my keys, I bring my hands,” she said, and packed a bag like a midwife.

We drove at dusk, the sky a bruise, the road stitching fields to one another with a line so straight it felt like a dare. Buckley’s house had three chairs on a porch even though there were six residents, which told me a lot about their fights. Inside, the air held a mixture of onions and oil and something sweet. He lay on the couch, not pretending the couch did not shame him by being a couch and not a bed. His sisters were younger, all of them with long hair they obviously took turns combing. Everything in that room had been touched too many times and was not ashamed of it.

He watched Darla with a distrust so pure it was almost a kind of honesty I wished I could bottle and give to every judge I’d ever stood before. She asked what she should ask, then asked what none of us ever ask because we pretend bodies are the only site of pain. “Who told you you weren’t allowed to be scared,” she said. He cried like a man learning a word in a language he pretended he didn’t want to speak.

I stood in the doorway like furniture. I looked at the curtains, which were made of a fabric I recognized from the chain-store in town that sells everything and nothing at a price that makes you feel complicit. The hem had been taken up with a contrasting thread, a quick job done by a hand that assumed no one would be rude enough to notice. I noticed, and loved whoever had done it for refusing to apologize for haste. We left a cooler with things that will never be cooler enough for anyone who has had to use one to hold medicine. As we drove away, a dog chased the car for the first ten feet and then remembered his other duty, which was to sit on the porch and guard the chairs.

The letter from the state came the next morning, and I understood immediately what Sloan had meant about the wrong door. It was written in the unadorned tone of people who have been taught, usually by loss, that adornment should be rationed. It asked the board to explain, in writing, why its waiver process required three months even when a physician’s request included language about imminent decline. It asked for dates. It asked for copies of donor agreements in which practices were “suggested,” a word that can mean a lot if you were raised to hear nuance, and can mean nothing if you live in a house where nuance is a cousin nobody invites because he never brings a dish. I took the letter to McCreedy’s office myself, because I wanted to see his face absorb it, and because I am, at heart, childish enough to enjoy a legal delivery that feels like a dessert hurled low across a long table.

The receptionist, whose nails were a miracle of patience and tiny art, asked if I had an appointment. I smiled and said I had a public document with a private effect. She looked at me the way women look at men who enjoy awakening the appetite of the room for drama, and then buzzed me through. McCreedy stood with his back to the window, a tall man whose suits always fit like a hand-laundered shirt on a child. His hair was the color of money and he used gel the way some men use prayer. He took the letter, smiled to show he knew what was in it, then let the smile slip to show me it could slip when he wanted.

“You’re making a mess, Barry,” he said pleasantly. “This town likes tidiness. I’m trying to protect your career from your convictions.”

“I’m trying to protect your convictions from your career,” I said, and he laughed because the line was too good to ignore, even for someone who prefers a dull sentence to a smart blade any day. He tapped the corner of the letter against his desk and then set it down as if the page might bruise. When he looked at me again, I saw the calculation men like him cannot resist. Am I the thing to be bent, he was wondering, or do I carry my own metal.

When men decide to harm you in Meridian, they call your mother’s pastor and ask him to pray for you out loud on a Sunday for a thing you did not do. If your mother is dead, they call the pastor anyway, because they prefer their weapons consecrated. The next weekend, a friend sent me a clip from a service in which the pastor called down wisdom on those “who are lured by the lights of arrogant science and forget to be small,” and while I do not name myself a Christian anymore, I know a parable when I hear one and I know a cudgel when I am struck with it. After church, at the grocery, two women I’d known since grade school turned their heads at the exact same angle so their hair made a curtain and their mouths could work in that quick, righteous way. The aisle with the canned beans has never felt so long.

Sloan, who has spent his whole life in rooms where other people pretend not to move the furniture while you are seated on it, called me and did not say I told you so. “I am finding that when I hum while I write a brief, my sentences relax,” he told me instead, as if reporting a symptom. “My assistant thinks I have lost my mind. The mind that did that work deserved to be lost. I’m beginning a motion with a story. Do you believe me? I am terrified.”

“Terroir makes better arguments,” I said, because I read that somewhere and wanted it to be true about everything.

He hummed on the line without meaning to, and I pictured his mouth, which had never entertained much softness, shaping around the note. “They will file a bar complaint,” he said. “You should know. There is a woman whose business it is to write such things for people who cannot bring themselves to say them aloud. She wrote mine when I prosecuted the wrong boy a lifetime ago, and I will never use her again, because she made me excellent and I hated it. She is on retainer to the warehouse people. I don’t want you surprised.”

“I like being surprised,” I lied, because some lies are less about the truth and more about practicing a posture. He hung up and I put the phone on the kitchen counter and pressed my palms into the laminate until the cheap pattern printed itself on my skin. When I lifted my hands, the pale ovals faded fast, which felt like an omen I chose not to interpret.

Joy texted me a photo of her lab sheet with a single number circled and a row of confetti emojis she would not have deigned to use two months ago. “I feel like I swallowed the right seed,” she wrote. “Maybe it will sprout an ugly flower and I won’t care.”

“Plant anything,” I wrote back. “Even weeds have the decency to try.”

That night, I dreamt the courthouse steps were made of fabric and each time I took a step my foot sank an inch and a needle poked up from the next rung to tell me, with a sting, to be careful. When I woke, my chest hurt the way it does in the dreams where you run too fast in one direction and realize the floor has tilted. I made coffee that tasted like grief then tried again and made coffee that tasted like medium resolve. The mail came with an envelope that had the weight of a menacing invitation. The bar complaint alleged that I had advised a physician to prescribe outside of protocol for personal gain and had “marketed claims of miracle” to the detriment of an unnamed population. It cited the radio appearance Pil had insisted on. It cited a sentence from an online article at a site everyone knows and no one admits to reading, which had called me “mercurial and emotional,” both of which are true and neither of which is illegal.

I took the complaint to the one person in town besides me who keeps file folders alphabetized but not color-coded because color-coding, she says, is a religion she refuses to practice. Mrs. Hale has been practicing law since before I could pronounce tort properly, and she smells like cedar and the inside of library books that have been stored well. She read it with her eyebrows lifting at regular intervals and then she put her finger on my name at the top as if to anchor me and said, “They don’t know how you learned to sew. They think you only learned to rip. You’ll be fine.”

“I’m tired of being fine,” I said. “I want to be loud and right and forgiven.”

“You can pick two,” she said crisply, then softened. “It feels bigger because it is. It’s bigger because we haven’t done this before and you are arrogant enough to pretend you know how. Thank God for arrogance, sometimes. It keeps us out of trouble and it drags us toward the places trouble turned into a map.”

On the day of the administrative hearing, Meridian chose humidity as a weapon. The room had a fan but it clicked, and the clerk, out of loyalty to silence, turned it off while we spoke. The panel sat in their chairs as if the chairs were electric and would shock them if they leaned too far in any direction. Sloan stood and, true to his word, began with a story about a boy who hummed while he did his homework and got hit with a ruler because humming has no place in math. He said he had spent his career learning to do the kind of work that makes humming illegal and he was here to ask to reverse a very small law in a very small place.

“We are not asking to change the way medicine is practiced in the world,” he said. “We are asking to make room for a thing that is happening while we speak. I have seen the numbers. I have seen the faces behind them. They look like the people who attended my wedding and the people who avoided it. They look like this town.”

The warehouse men sat in the back, their shirts gleaming absurdly. One of them had a pinky ring that caught the lights whenever he shifted his hand, and I had a childish fantasy of stealing it and dropping it into a glass of water to watch it fizz. Darla spoke next, and she was as precise as I have ever heard anyone be. She used phrases that made the panel blink because their cadence belonged to rooms where people speak quietly so sorrow does not run too fast. She said off-label as if labeling were a superstition and not a comfort. She said adverse event and the room’s very few children, dragged there because their babysitters fell through, turned their faces because they recognize the tone adults use when they want to say death but cannot.

When it was my turn, I did not make it about my mother. I wanted to, because my heart is a noisy snob. I spoke instead about the plainest part of the law: its decent wish to give a person not a past but a future. I said the phrase “reasonable choice” twice and only knocked my knuckle against the table once, by accident, which counts as progress for a man like me. At the edge of the room, a woman whose sister had been Joy’s nurse for three months started to cry openly, and no one told her to leave, and that felt like we had done one thing right whether or not we won what was on the paper.

We did not win. Of course we did not. The panel deferred, which is a kind of slap you deliver with a silk glove when you don’t want to bruise the hand but do want to remind it who owns the glove. We filed out into a heat so generous even enemies felt briefly bonded by it. One of the warehouse men brushed past me and said, his voice like candy dropped in a church pew, “We needed to see if you frighten easy. You do not. That is inconvenient for us.” He smiled and added, almost regretful, “We will have to be creative. Creativity is not what we pay for.”

That night Darla called at eleven to say Joy’s temperature had spiked. There are words that cut through a phone line and rearrange the furniture in your chest. Spike is one. I put on shoes without socks and drove too fast and did not apologize to the two yellow lights I made deals with. Joy’s face burned and her eyes were so clear they looked like someone had polished them to sell them in a store. Carrow had sent instructions and a dose and a warning, and we followed all three as if we were learning a dance with music we considered personal. The room smelled like water. Earl stood in the doorway as if the door had hired him to be the respectable face of alarm.

The fever broke at three the way thin ice breaks under a foot that deserves to be forgiven for the trouble it causes. Her hair plastered to her head and she looked like a girl again and not like a saint, which I prefer because saints are exhausting and girls are what the world is made for. Darla sat on the floor because chairs had become untrustworthy. She rested her head against the cabinet and laughed into her own shoulder, which is the kind of laugh you do when you’re afraid other people will misunderstand happiness if you let it out loose.

We went outside because the room had been too much a body. The air had that fresh metallic thing again, and I know it is only the smell of wet concrete and the way the night plays tricks but I will call it mercy. Sloan sent a text with a photo of a sheet of music with four measures filled, pencil dark at the edges like he had pressed too hard because the day had asked too much. Underneath, he wrote, “I moved air again,” and I wrote back as carefully as I could, “You are allowed.”

As we stood there, a small truck rolled slowly down the street and then slowed more, then stopped. This is a town where stopping is not suspicious until it is. The window rolled down and the man whose teeth were too straight leaned out and said almost sorrowfully, “You keep choosing the loudest form of your courage. We prefer the quiet kind.” He took a picture of us in the street with a sound that made me think of a zipper, then drove on as gently as he had arrived, and for a second we looked down at our bodies to see if the photograph had removed anything visible.

“I’m tired of their good grammar,” Darla said, and went back inside to watch her patient breathe. I stood there and marveled, the way I have since boyhood, at how very little holds anything where it is, how much of what keeps a town from falling down is the habit of shoes on the same boards and the way we know how to turn a corner without falling apart. My phone buzzed. The state administrator wanted to meet in person in Jackson to talk about a pilot program they might not be allowed to call a pilot program. She’d be on the steps at noon with a folder that looked like any other folder and would contain an invitation she could not hand me without pretending it was a reprimand.

“I’ll bring a reprimand folder of my own,” I wrote back, because there are games even I enjoy playing.

I went home and sat in my kitchen and looked at my hands. The crease between thumb and forefinger had a tiny nick in it, right where fast things catch you, and when I flexed my fingers the cut stretched and threatened to split. I sucked on it without thinking, a child’s cure, and tasted faint iron. In the other room, my mother’s quilt hung over the back of a chair, the light catching on the places where her stitches are tighter because my father had left that week and you can see it if you know how to read such things. I ran my fingers over one row and then the next, feeling the bumps like Braille, as if the fabric might tell me what to do next, as if she had hidden directions there, as if the whole world were a garment and somebody had, at last, handed me a needle I knew how to hold.Chapter 5

The state administrator wore her authority like a linen dress that had seen a careful iron and a careless day. On the steps in Jackson, she stood with a folder so plain it broadcast its own decency, chin lifted not in pride but in habit. Her name was Lorraine Keys, which felt right because you could hear how often she had opened things and how little she had been thanked for it. She extended the folder as if she might be seen on a Baptist postcard doing a similar act with a casserole, and then she smiled in a way that let me know how deeply she had practiced believing polite forms could hold impolite truths until those truths learned to sit up straight.

“Mr. Barrett,” she said, and her voice had the grain of someone who had trained it to move through rooms full of men without knocking china. “This is a reprimand.”

“I adore reprimands,” I said softly. “They go with all my suits.”

“Inside,” she continued, not indulging my bad habit, “you’ll find a letter asking Saint Rose to clarify its waiver process, a draft schedule for a site visit by my office, and two pages that we’re not supposed to have written yet because they belong to an initiative without a budget or a blessing. We will call it a study for as long as that makes anyone feel safer. Between us, it is a pilot.”

“I knew I liked you,” I said, and she tilted her head a fraction, fighting the smile that wants to run ahead of a woman’s work and take credit. She pointed to a bench and we sat like strangers about to trade recipes.

“I lost my sister at twenty-six,” Lorraine said plainly, and the sentence walked itself into my body without asking for permission. “They said there was nothing to be done and then, three years later, there was something to be done and the town that got it first had better handwriting and a man with a lake house. I put a dent in my desk the week I learned that. The dent is still there, and I run my fingers over it when I’m deciding who I’m angry at.”

“I am here to be useful to your anger,” I said. “And to your restraint.”

She nodded. “Good. Because we will need both. I can’t protect you from donors. I can shelter a protocol if we are tidy and if we do not insist the applause precede the work. I will need data that doesn’t look like greed. I will need, especially, a physician who prefers bone-marrow honesty to applause.”

“Darla,” I said. “She runs on that.”

“Good,” Lorraine said again. “She will sit on a committee that does not yet exist. You will not. I know your type. Your talent is for throwing open windows and then holding them against a storm. In governance, that makes the papers warp. I mean that kindly.”

“Kind is the word I live for,” I said, which is true and feels cheap every time I say it. She tapped the folder and looked out over the parking lot as if it were a plainsong she had memorized and couldn’t stop humming.

“They will come at supply,” she said without drama. “You do not need to know how I know. You need only to plan for it. If your town is held together by warehouse men, those men understand that the easiest way to make a doctor behave is to make her wait on a truck. They will not make the drug vanish. They will make the paperwork multiply until you believe it is a forest.”

“I know a man who is learning to cut paths,” I said, and thought of Sloan’s mouth shaping notes, his fingers tapping time against his desk. “He will not like being told where to walk.”

Lorraine stood with that briskness women in flats learn so no one thinks their shoes make them slow. “Use the letter. Do not quote me. When they tell you you’re arrogant, try not to prove them right while understanding they will call you arrogant either way. Bring me numbers. Bring me faces only when you must. My staff has very good hearts and poor circulation in their faces; they cannot hear mothers without weeping and it embarrasses them and then they do dumb things with policy.”

She left with the humility of someone who has learned the cost of being looked at, and I sat on the warm stone and read the reprimand with a hungry pleasure. It was written in the kind of English that believes verbs should be tools: ask, clarify, explain. At the back of the packet, two untitled pages laid out a plain miracle: a registry with teeth, emergency waivers at the department level when boards stalled, and a line reserving a chair for a “practicing oncologist from an affected community” that had Darla’s shape all over it. I folded the papers small and tucked them where I would not lose them, inside the lining of my jacket in the down-left pocket my tailor had installed because he did not trust me to keep anything precious where it could be reached in a hurry.

On the drive back, the radio offered a gospel station that bleeds into the frequency Pil uses when storms fret with our towers. A choir lifted a chord so clean I wanted to pull over and iron my day. The tilt of the sun made the magnolia leaves look like coins flipping in the air and coming up the side that feeds you. At a light, a farmer in a truck as old as my regrets glanced over and nodded, and I nodded back with the half-smile men here use when they do not want to be accused of tenderness.

At Saint Rose, Darla stood in the cruel fluorescent of the lobby like a saint nobody would paint because her hair had escaped its pin and she’d committed the unpardonable sin of existing in relief. She took the folder, scanned the phrases with the flinch of someone half-expecting to find her own name misspelled and her credentials misremembered, then exhaled like a small puncture in a stubborn tire.

“She did it,” she said, and I felt, for a second, the lovely silly wish to invite Lorraine to supper and cut her a second piece of pie without making a fuss. “They will call it a reprimand. We will call it anatomy. We need a body to pour this work into.”

“A registry with teeth,” I said, and the phrase tasted satisfying. “You get a chair. They will pretend to have invented you.”

“They can have the credit,” she said, and her mouth insisted it wasn’t a lie and her eyes asked me to remember to argue for her when she forgot she was owed. “Joy’s hair sprouted insultingly early this morning. Two millimeters of bravado along her temple. Earl cried about something on the television and blamed the weather.”

“Let me see her,” I said. “I need to recalibrate my face. I’ve been in Jackson where people are paid to control the muscles around their mouths.”

Joy had propped her phone on the tray so she could watch a video of a woman teaching a bird to say something impolite. She waved without pausing the lesson because priorities line up differently when your body has been trying to leave you without your permission. The fuzz along her hairline really was audacious, like a field testifying that green can be a verb even after a fire. Her cheeks had bloomed that dangerous pink that means nothing and everything. When I told her about the registry-that-was-not and the chair-that-was, she nodded like a small mayor.

“Good,” she said. “Make it so it doesn’t depend on me staying charming.”

“You were never charming,” I said. “You were honest and people keep mislabeling you because honesty sounds like a joke when you’re used to compliments.”

She laughed and her mother’s face folded with gratitude so intense it looked like pain. Before I could name that, before I could ruin it by observing it too closely, my phone buzzed with a text from Aimee that did the work of a siren while pretending to be a whisper. The antibiotic had been marked on backorder by both of the large wholesalers who feed our small pharmacies. The reason field read: compliance. The second text contained a photograph of a man at the backdoor of our office holding a clipboard and a smile that had never been a child.

Aimee had written only, It begins, and when a secretary who has raised two sons and a business writes a sentence like that without an exclamation mark, you listen like it’s thunder.

The warehouse men had nudged the river and then complained about the flood. The antibiotic wasn’t special, except now it was. The generic wasn’t common, except now it was rare in the way bread becomes rare in a snowstorm because everyone wants to remember what comfort tastes like. Aimee told the clipboard that any paperwork could be slid under our door because moving our rug was something she refused to perform for men she did not invite. The clipboard’s smile stayed pinned but his eyes did what eyes do when they know the house is not afraid of them.

Darla stood with her hand on the back of Joy’s chair, thumb moving in a small rhythm that told me she was doing math. “There are animal versions,” she said. “Different concentration, same root. I will not poison anyone’s daughter to spite a man’s cousin. But I will make calls to every large animal vet within a hundred miles and I will look them in the soul and ask them what they see when they look back.”

“Pil has a cousin,” I said automatically, because in Meridian everything you need is someone’s cousin if you mark your map with enough pushpins. “He runs a feed store that has the air of a confessional. I’ll talk to him. We will not have you feeding cattle pills to children. We will smooth this bureaucratically while we hunt in fields the board doesn’t know how to plow.”

As if summoned by audacity, Sloan called. He sounded thinner and stronger, like a wire pulled taut enough to sing. “They will cut supply,” he said without introduction. “I’ve heard handshakes clicking all morning. Watch your pharmacies. I can’t criminally prosecute a backorder, but I can ask questions in rooms that do not enjoy questions.”

“We have a state folder with a reprimand that asks for sunlight,” I told him. “Lorraine sent it. We are to pretend we feel chagrined.”

“Good,” he said, and the word held a note I hadn’t heard from him since we were young men rehearsing our shrugs in different mirrors. “I am filing a public records request for procurement emails at Saint Rose and for any communications including the phrase ‘alternate source’ or ‘temporary substitution.’ Their IT will groan. My staff will hate me. My wife will love me for being someone she thought she had to misremember.”

There was a pause at the back of his breath, and then he said, “I moved on from humming. I wrote something that had the rudeness to be pretty. If you hear someone whistling in the courthouse, pretend you don’t know who it is.”

“Whistle louder,” I said. “Men in good suits are allergic.”

He laughed, and it wasn’t the tidy laugh you do when the room expects a noise; it was the kind that steals some of the heat from a day and gives it back when it has cooled it enough to hold.

Pil’s cousin, whose name was Boone because of course it was, stood behind a counter piled with salt blocks, dewormer, and things I could not ethically confess to recognizing. He wore a hat that had known good summers and bad fence lines. When I mentioned the drug, he did not tilt his head like someone hearing a new thing. He ran his finger along the shelf tag like a man reading the future in tea leaves and then glanced at me with a frankness that would have ruined a less honest face.

“You’re not the first to ask,” he said. “Last week Mrs. Ludwig drove down from across the river and bought two bottles after asking me five questions to make me feel like she had read a book about cattle she did not own. I sold her one. I can read a mother, but I can also count inventory. I will not keep a man from curing a calf because men here name their animals and cry when they pretend they don’t. I can get you three bottles if you ask me as if I’m your cousin, and not the way you ask for something illegal that isn’t.”

“I’m asking because my cousin is brave,” I said. “And because a warehouse man wants to teach us who has hands.”

Boone nodded like I’d finally made a sentence worth hearing. He boxed the bottles with a solemnity that looked like prayer and took my money like it was a story I was letting him borrow. As he slid the package across, he said, “Tell your doctor that if she wants to sleep, she’ll have to do it in the afternoon. Nights have gone sticky with people who want to be fixed while other people sleep.”

I left the feed store holding a cardboard cube that seemed to vibrate with metaphor if not with chemistry. It was not our solution. It was our insult to scarcity. Aimee texted me a photograph of the clipboard man sitting in his car with the kind of patience men practice when they believe their waiting is the waiting that counts. She had drawn horns on him with the notes app pen and sent a second text that said simply, lunch? I wrote back that I would bring her a sandwich that would make her consider forgiving me for becoming a crusader without asking her to buy more paper.

By late afternoon, the hospital smelled like the inside of a freezer-case because the air had decided to snap, and our blood was still on the soft setting. The board sent a memo telling staff to “expect a routine disruption” as part of the site visit, which is a sentence only people with wood-paneled offices write and only people without keys to any room will be asked to believe. Darla read it in the hallway, crumpled it without grace, then smoothed it with the heel of her hand because a woman who has spent her life coaxing tissues to behave does not throw paper away unpressed.

“Let them disrupt in public,” she said. “I am tired of being scolded behind glass.”

Joy wanted the river. It was a good request masquerading as a bad idea. We loaded her gently into Earl’s truck with the reverence men give things they are not trained to hold. The air near the water was thick with a humming that wasn’t mechanical. The current did its quiet arithmetic, shouldering what the town handed it. Joy sat on the bank with her shoes off, toes in the mud like a small pagan, head tilted back to bite the light. She looked less like a patient than like a girl whose body had just learned summer again.

“Do you think the fish know anything about us,” she asked without turning, “or are we the kind of animals they tolerate the way we tolerate lightning?”

“We are a rumor to fish,” I said. “But a loud one.”

She wiggled her toes and grinned. “Good. I am tired of being a lesson. I would rather be noise.”

Behind us, someone played a violin on a porch. At first, I thought it was a radio, because the notes landed too assured for a man in Meridian on a Tuesday, and then I saw Oakes in the doorway of a little rental with a slumping roof. He had kept the violin as I’d told him to, and the way his jaw set said he had paid for that choice with something domestic and complicated. The tune was old enough to belong to nobody, and young enough to make my chest feel like it had been laced tighter than style or propriety required. It wasn’t quite sad. It was the sound a seam makes when it holds under strain.

Oakes waved with his bow and then went back to the work of making air behave. Across the road, a sheriff’s cruiser idled in the shade as if it had been assigned to watch the water for crimes it did not wish to find. The deputy lifted his fingers in that universal gesture of a man who has seen too much and still wants to be seen as decent. The warehouse men did not appear, but the fact of them sat on the grass like a hat nobody admitted to owning.

We did not stay past dusk because the mosquitoes here are thorough and prefer the ankles of the idealistic. Back in town, I found a note taped to my door written in the florid hand of someone proud of their penmanship and uninterested in its uses. It did not threaten so much as curate: a list of names, each with a year beside it, men and women who had filed for bankruptcy after crossing the McCreedy cousins on matters of distribution. At the bottom, in tiny letters like an afterthought sewn into a hem, the question again: do you keep what’s inside inside. I understood, not for the first time, that I was being addressed by someone who had misunderstood sewing as surgery.

I took the list to Mrs. Hale, who was in her office stapling something with a vigor that suggested she believed she could attach the world to itself and keep it from fraying. She read it, lifted one eyebrow as if speaking privately to it, and slid it into a sleeve in a binder that would be labeled something like Antagonists: Accomplishments which is a system I respect more every time I see her use it.
