Darla stood with her hand on the back of Joy’s chair, thumb moving in a small rhythm that told me she was doing math. “There are animal versions,” she said. “Different concentration, same root. I will not poison anyone’s daughter to spite a man’s cousin. But I will make calls to every large animal vet within a hundred miles and I will look them in the soul and ask them what they see when they look back.”

“Pil has a cousin,” I said automatically, because in Meridian everything you need is someone’s cousin if you mark your map with enough pushpins. “He runs a feed store that has the air of a confessional. I’ll talk to him. We will not have you feeding cattle pills to children. We will smooth this bureaucratically while we hunt in fields the board doesn’t know how to plow.”

As if summoned by audacity, Sloan called. He sounded thinner and stronger, like a wire pulled taut enough to sing. “They will cut supply,” he said without introduction. “I’ve heard handshakes clicking all morning. Watch your pharmacies. I can’t criminally prosecute a backorder, but I can ask questions in rooms that do not enjoy questions.”

“We have a state folder with a reprimand that asks for sunlight,” I told him. “Lorraine sent it. We are to pretend we feel chagrined.”

“Good,” he said, and the word held a note I hadn’t heard from him since we were young men rehearsing our shrugs in different mirrors. “I am filing a public records request for procurement emails at Saint Rose and for any communications including the phrase ‘alternate source’ or ‘temporary substitution.’ Their IT will groan. My staff will hate me. My wife will love me for being someone she thought she had to misremember.”

There was a pause at the back of his breath, and then he said, “I moved on from humming. I wrote something that had the rudeness to be pretty. If you hear someone whistling in the courthouse, pretend you don’t know who it is.”

“Whistle louder,” I said. “Men in good suits are allergic.”

He laughed, and it wasn’t the tidy laugh you do when the room expects a noise; it was the kind that steals some of the heat from a day and gives it back when it has cooled it enough to hold.

Pil’s cousin, whose name was Boone because of course it was, stood behind a counter piled with salt blocks, dewormer, and things I could not ethically confess to recognizing. He wore a hat that had known good summers and bad fence lines. When I mentioned the drug, he did not tilt his head like someone hearing a new thing. He ran his finger along the shelf tag like a man reading the future in tea leaves and then glanced at me with a frankness that would have ruined a less honest face.

“You’re not the first to ask,” he said. “Last week Mrs. Ludwig drove down from across the river and bought two bottles after asking me five questions to make me feel like she had read a book about cattle she did not own. I sold her one. I can read a mother, but I can also count inventory. I will not keep a man from curing a calf because men here name their animals and cry when they pretend they don’t. I can get you three bottles if you ask me as if I’m your cousin, and not the way you ask for something illegal that isn’t.”

“I’m asking because my cousin is brave,” I said. “And because a warehouse man wants to teach us who has hands.”

Boone nodded like I’d finally made a sentence worth hearing. He boxed the bottles with a solemnity that looked like prayer and took my money like it was a story I was letting him borrow. As he slid the package across, he said, “Tell your doctor that if she wants to sleep, she’ll have to do it in the afternoon. Nights have gone sticky with people who want to be fixed while other people sleep.”

I left the feed store holding a cardboard cube that seemed to vibrate with metaphor if not with chemistry. It was not our solution. It was our insult to scarcity. Aimee texted me a photograph of the clipboard man sitting in his car with the kind of patience men practice when they believe their waiting is the waiting that counts. She had drawn horns on him with the notes app pen and sent a second text that said simply, lunch? I wrote back that I would bring her a sandwich that would make her consider forgiving me for becoming a crusader without asking her to buy more paper.

By late afternoon, the hospital smelled like the inside of a freezer-case because the air had decided to snap, and our blood was still on the soft setting. The board sent a memo telling staff to “expect a routine disruption” as part of the site visit, which is a sentence only people with wood-paneled offices write and only people without keys to any room will be asked to believe. Darla read it in the hallway, crumpled it without grace, then smoothed it with the heel of her hand because a woman who has spent her life coaxing tissues to behave does not throw paper away unpressed.

“Let them disrupt in public,” she said. “I am tired of being scolded behind glass.”

Joy wanted the river. It was a good request masquerading as a bad idea. We loaded her gently into Earl’s truck with the reverence men give things they are not trained to hold. The air near the water was thick with a humming that wasn’t mechanical. The current did its quiet arithmetic, shouldering what the town handed it. Joy sat on the bank with her shoes off, toes in the mud like a small pagan, head tilted back to bite the light. She looked less like a patient than like a girl whose body had just learned summer again.

“Do you think the fish know anything about us,” she asked without turning, “or are we the kind of animals they tolerate the way we tolerate lightning?”

“We are a rumor to fish,” I said. “But a loud one.”

She wiggled her toes and grinned. “Good. I am tired of being a lesson. I would rather be noise.”

Behind us, someone played a violin on a porch. At first, I thought it was a radio, because the notes landed too assured for a man in Meridian on a Tuesday, and then I saw Oakes in the doorway of a little rental with a slumping roof. He had kept the violin as I’d told him to, and the way his jaw set said he had paid for that choice with something domestic and complicated. The tune was old enough to belong to nobody, and young enough to make my chest feel like it had been laced tighter than style or propriety required. It wasn’t quite sad. It was the sound a seam makes when it holds under strain.

Oakes waved with his bow and then went back to the work of making air behave. Across the road, a sheriff’s cruiser idled in the shade as if it had been assigned to watch the water for crimes it did not wish to find. The deputy lifted his fingers in that universal gesture of a man who has seen too much and still wants to be seen as decent. The warehouse men did not appear, but the fact of them sat on the grass like a hat nobody admitted to owning.

We did not stay past dusk because the mosquitoes here are thorough and prefer the ankles of the idealistic. Back in town, I found a note taped to my door written in the florid hand of someone proud of their penmanship and uninterested in its uses. It did not threaten so much as curate: a list of names, each with a year beside it, men and women who had filed for bankruptcy after crossing the McCreedy cousins on matters of distribution. At the bottom, in tiny letters like an afterthought sewn into a hem, the question again: do you keep what’s inside inside. I understood, not for the first time, that I was being addressed by someone who had misunderstood sewing as surgery.

I took the list to Mrs. Hale, who was in her office stapling something with a vigor that suggested she believed she could attach the world to itself and keep it from fraying. She read it, lifted one eyebrow as if speaking privately to it, and slid it into a sleeve in a binder that would be labeled something like Antagonists: Accomplishments which is a system I respect more every time I see her use it.

“They will exhaust you,” she said, and poured me tea that tasted like someone had put lemon across the threshold and then asked it to wait outside. “Win quick where you can. Lose with elegance where you must. Don’t snarl unless you are willing to bite. And for the love of all that is holy, do not trip over your own cape.”

“I would need to own a cape,” I said. “I’m still at the scarf stage.”

“Men in scarves,” she said drily, “are a menace if they don’t understand their necks are vulnerable. Your client with the violin sent me a note. He wants a new will. He has fallen in love with a woman who sells perfume and refuses to borrow money from him, and he says this has rearranged his sense of justice. Tell him to come in Wednesday. I like women who refuse.”

The next morning began with a thud that resolved into a letterbox chewing up something thick. The bar had docketed the complaint. It had a hearing date that suggested the clerk who chose it enjoyed planting events where they could ruin your favorite lunch. Aimee read the notice, then walked to my office and closed the door like she was making a room in which I might be allowed to be less brave.

“You need to sleep in this chair with your jacket on and your shoes off for thirty minutes,” she said. “If you do not, you will make a mistake on paper that will make me embarrassed to call your mother a good woman.”

“I like your priorities,” I said, and set my phone on the desk face down like a sinner laying down a weapon. She turned off the light and left the door cracked the way you do for a child, and I slept for twenty-two minutes and woke with a damp line where my face had made claims on the upholstery. In the dim, the office looked both foreign and delighted to have me vulnerable. I sat up slower than my day wanted and poured coffee with that trembling care you learn when you’ve spilled too much lately.

Sloan beat me to the courthouse. When I arrived, he was steps from the rotunda, shirt sleeves rolled, tie loosened in a concession to the weather and to his sudden insistence that performances can be better for refusing some of their costumes. He held a sheaf of papers that looked like all the others and were not. At the top, in a font the secretaries favor because it suggests decency without announcing taste, the words Motion for Protective Order: Supply Interference sat with a calm that made me love my language again.

“They’ll say I’m inventing a cause,” he said, before I could praise him. “I’m not. I am stitching two causes together where they should have been introduced years ago. Restraint of trade does not become virtuous because a donor likes the company Christmas party.”

“You hummed when you wrote that title,” I said, and he looked down like a boy caught putting jam on the good knife.

“I did,” he said. “And I kept my job through lunch.”

The hearing room smelled like dry books and men who decline water because they fear its softness. The judge wore his robe like a thin apology and his expression like a compromise with regret. Sloan spoke with that new slight lean he’d found, the one that said he had discovered he had a body and it could carry him without cruelty. He did not mention Joy by name. He did not say cancer. He spoke about scarcity erected on purpose, about the difference between delay that saves life and delay that buys yachts. He used a word I hadn’t heard him use before in a court: mercy.

“Both sides like to argue as if we are in separate shops,” he said mildly. “As if the law sells only tools and medicine sells only cures. We do not. We both sell time. Today I am asking you to sell it to the people with the least, rather than to the people with the most. It will sting someone. It always does.”

McCreedy’s lawyer, who had a talent for leaving no footprint on a rug, stood and said the phrase “overreach” with the unctuous authority of a man who has never reached for anything that wasn’t handed to him. He smiled toward me like a man offering a seat on a boat he planned to sink when we got out a little ways. The judge listened with his head tilted, that foxlike posture you develop when you are being asked to bless something you know you’ll meet again in a different robe. He took the motion and did not grant it. He took the motion and did not deny it. He did something I love him forever for and resent him the next hour over: he asked for an evidentiary hearing with affidavits from any pharmacist willing to write the sentence “I was told to delay.”

“This will make someone lose a job,” Sloan said after, in the hallway that remembers every whisper. “I am done being the man who arranges for the wrong people to lose jobs.”

“They will come for yours,” I said. “They already have their pencils out.”

“I bought a new one for myself,” he said, and when I looked at his hand I saw he had a blister where his music had been practicing being heavier than the law.

By dinner, Pil had wrangled me onto the radio again because he believes in repetition the way grandmothers believe in butter. We talked around the supply, we talked toward the hearing, we did not say the word boycott, we said the phrase quiet harm, and the phones did their red show. A woman confessed that she had been told, once, to wait for a scan until the fiscal quarter turned over. A man admitted he had swapped labels in a stockroom because the only power he’d been given was his handwriting and he had decided it could save a life. Neither hung up on time because people who have been carrying their stories need a runway long enough to lift them.

Sometime after nine, while I was still at the office pretending to tidy the stack of papers that had adopted me, the building breathed differently. The old hat store has a way of telling you when someone has opened its door even if that someone is trying to muscle their way into invisibility. A floorboard to the left of the stair creaked, not the friendly sound of Aimee’s heels but the reluctant sound of a man in soft soles. I stood and did not reach for anything heavier than my own spine.

“You can come in,” I said, and the man with the straight teeth entered like a neighbor with a pie, only there was no dish and his hands were empty as a sermon that has decided to be cruel. He did not sit. He inspected my suit with his eyes and I let him, which is a small power, allowing someone to measure you by their own tape.

“We prefer back channels,” he said, patient as a parent with a child picking at a scab. “You have made us noisy. Noisy costs money. Do you know how many trucks we turn around when the radio makes the town think it deserves to perform its own medicine?”

“Fewer than you did last week, if the state has anything to say,” I said. “Which it does. Nicely. With a folder.”

He paced my office without shoes squeaking because men like him buy soles that have remembered how to behave. He looked at my bookshelf, the cheap law books dressed up by my vanity with two hardcovers that had dust jackets I hadn’t removed because I married the phrase first edition once and never wanted to divorce it.

“We can be friends,” he said. “It is not a threat. It is a promise. We can find a way to make your doctor’s experiment live inside a carton we control. You like control. Lawyers pretend they don’t and then you see them count their pens.”

“You will not own this,” I said. “There are things this town doesn’t get to own anymore. Grief. Air. The protocols for mercy.”

He stood still then, like someone had whispered a note he’d been trying to find on an instrument he never learned. For a second, I saw the child he probably had been, the one who lined his toy cars in ranks not to be cruel but to impose order on a day that had no parent in it. Then his face shuttered like a window people are too gentle to slam.

“Order keeps people from dying,” he said. “Chaos kills. Your project is chaos in Sunday clothes.”

“Order without ethics is ash in a box you convince yourself is a church,” I said, and he smiled like a teacher generously awarding me a B-plus.

“I will take your metaphor to lunch,” he said. “You will lose your license. I will not. Both things will be regrettable. We will both survive.”

He left without taking my air, which I count as a victory. I sat down and realized my hands had been clenched in my lap in a way my mother would have scolded me for at supper. I thought of Sloan’s blister, of Darla’s thumb tracing quiet circles on the back of a chair, of Lorraine’s folder tucked like a heart into my jacket. I thought of Joy holding water with her feet, asking the river to remember her. Somewhere in town, Oakes was playing the last notes of a thing that had no name and that did not need one, and the warehouse men were doing math and the state was building a file cabinet for a kind of mercy that had never had its own drawer.

Just before midnight, when the town does its loudest pretending at being quiet, my phone lit with a text from an unknown number and the words that can unmake a day or fortify it. I have receipts, it said. The photograph that followed was of an invoice from a month ago for a pallet of the very antibiotic we were begging for, marked paid by a shell company whose mailing address belonged to a church’s dead P.O. box. The signature at the bottom had been obscured with one of those clumsy black bars people use when they think they’ve learned the law from a television show. If you brightened the image, the bar went transparent at the edges and a little curve of an M showed through, the way thread does if you lift the seam to the light.

Bring coffee, the second text read. And a needle. I like men who can mend.

Chapter 6

The text had that briskness people use when they’ve made a decision and they’re afraid they’ll unmake it if anyone speaks too long. I answered with a time and the address of the church on Pecan, the one with the brick face that looks too steady for the century that made it. The fellowship hall smells like coffee and card tables and floor wax that remembers being stronger. It is the only place in Meridian where secrets and casseroles are set next to each other without commentary. I packed two large cups from E.J.’s, the lids trembling like they didn’t like the heat they’d agreed to carry. Then I took my mother’s needle tin down from the top shelf, the shallow metal one with strawberries on the lid and a scuff where a life once dragged across it. The heft of it in my hand steadied me. It’s a ridiculous thing, to be calmed by a tin that rattles when you walk, but almost everything good in my life is ridiculous.

I arrived five minutes early because I refuse to make church ladies wait, even if I wasn’t certain my informant was one. The quilting circle had convened itself at the long tables, a loose congress of women who could run a legislature if asked and who have chosen, instead, to govern thread. Their hands moved while their mouths did, and if you’ve never seen a needle pierce a quilt in time with a story, you have not understood what choreography is. Miss Laverne, who looks like she smells of starch even when she doesn’t, lifted her chin toward a far table as if to say, Your witness is there, and also, do not drip coffee on the binding, I remember you as a child.

She sat apart with a posture that had practiced being unobtrusive and then decided, today, it would rather be noticed in the right way. She wore a dress in a faded flower, the kind that looks like it knows more seasons than your spine. Her hair was back with a clip you could buy for a dollar and then keep for twenty years. On the table in front of her lay a banner for a church homecoming, white satin with gold letters, the gold only a little gaudy, because even Methodists understand a festival requires a small sin. She did not extend her hand. She tapped two fingers on the banner hem and nodded once at the coffee.

“I’m Elise,” she said, and the name landed with a small weight I didn’t question. “I’m the one who checks the church P.O. box because Pastor Ray is too busy pretending mail is beneath him. This box has held Christmas letters, tithes from men who only like God at Easter, and every manner of passive-aggressive note a woman can send to another woman about committee work. Then it held invoices. Then it held checks.”

I slid the coffee toward her, careful of the satin, careful of the way she had positioned herself one step out of any safe light. She took a sip like a person who does not trust pleasure and then set the cup down with a sigh that said she remembered how it can save you.

“They like to name their companies decent,” she said, eyes on the hem. “This one is called Auxiliary Logistics. Auxiliary like helpful and logistics like they have a map. The return address is our old P.O. box with a new number written like a lie over an old truth. Their checks came from a foundation with a cross printed in the corner. I keep records because I was not allowed to go to college and I have been storing my learning in tidy marks and good paper ever since.”

“You have receipts,” I said, and she smiled without warmth, pleased I had not made her repeat herself.

“I have more than receipts,” she said. “I have their paper, and I have the shape of them. I have the right to be tired, and I have a friend at the pharmacy who tells me when the trucks are ‘delayed’ in a tone that means ‘not delayed.’ I have sent my nephew to take pictures of pallets in a storage unit with a lock that thinks it is admired. I have tucked a copy of all of it where church men won’t look, because they do not believe in hems.”

She pushed the banner toward me until the gold C of Christ wobbled and the satin whispered. I opened my mother’s tin and the old smell of metal and talc and something like time lifted out. The needle felt right between my fingers. The hall went quiet in that way rooms do when something more interesting than complaint arrives. I slid the point under the seam and teased. Satin resists politely and then relinquishes. I pulled the hem three inches and my breath slowed the way it does when a lock gives to your key.

From inside the false fold, she drew a sleeve, thin plastic, the kind you store photographs in when you promise yourself you will put them into an album and never do. Within, copies, thirty at least, of invoices and emails, some printed with that pale toner that says the printer hates the work it is doing. Names floated where they should not, not just the shell’s, not just the cousin’s, but a procurement manager at Saint Rose, two donor liaisons whose smiles have paid a mortgage, and one familiar curving M that completed itself when Elise held the page to the light just so.

“They will burn me for this if they can,” she said without ceremony. “They will call me jealous or silly or bitter or insane, and they will be correct at least once in their adjectives. I prefer brave. I prefer seamstress. I prefer citizen. I prefer woman who has had enough.”

“You are all of those,” I said, and I said it low because compliments sound truer when they are not performing into a microphone. “What do you need from me besides coffee and a needle?”

“I need you to carry this like the thing it is,” she said. “I need you to turn it into a file a man can’t pretend not to see. I need you to give it to someone with a hammer and then stand still while it hits and not flinch because you remember what flinching costs. I need you to keep my name out of the first story and, when it can be in safely, to put it there lovingly. I need you not to forget me if they ask you to.”

I promised the only way I know how, with my face. I tucked the sleeve into my brief bag the way you tuck a child into a coat that you do not trust to be warm enough. I resewed the banner with twice as many stitches as I had undone, because a seam like that deserves a redundancy and because women with scissors watched me and I did not intend to be rude.

“Will you stay and take a brownie you don’t deserve,” Miss Laverne called, which is how in Meridian you say you will be protected by something larger than you and it will not make the papers. Elise did not meet my eyes again. She ran her finger along the new seam, nodded once at the workmanship, and returned to stitching gold letters as if letters were any protection.

On the steps outside, the heat did its hawk impression. Sloan arrived at the same time as if summoned by a bell I had not heard. He had loosened his tie to the point that he might as well have taken it off, and his shirt sleeves looked like the part of a man that has been practicing confession. I lifted the sleeve of copies in my bag a fraction, and he inhaled like a doctor who has seen the color you hope for on a wound.

“Chain of custody,” he said, and for once the phrase sounded lovely. “We will do this like a lab. We will sign across tape. We will number pages. We will ask Elise—I assume that is her name—to write two paragraphs in her own hand and to tuck them in a Bible only she will touch, and we will not take them out until the judge asks us to, and we will hand him the book with respect.”

“She likes brave better than chain,” I said, “but she’ll do both.”

He asked nothing more until we were back at my office, because he understands that some stories must be allowed to ride in the backseat with the window open. Aimee had cleared her desk with that efficiency that pretends the top sheet was always supposed to be the top sheet. She produced labels with the gravity of a pharmacist. She produced a roll of red evidence tape from a drawer where she keeps things she hopes never to need. We numbered pages in a silence that dignified the mess. We signed across seams. We set the sleeve in a box we had not previously designated sacred and then did.

Lorraine answered my call on the first ring, which made me love her more than I had permission to. I told her what we had and she did not exclaim. She asked me to photograph one page that did not matter and to read aloud, slowly, the dates on three that did. She said the words “public interest” the way farmers say rain and the way mothers say enough. She gave us the name of a man in the attorney general’s office who cannot keep a secret and a woman in procurement who can. Then she said, “Bless the woman who hid that in a hem,” and hung up like her hands were already occupied with other mercies.

When we went to see Elise with a simple witness statement on letterhead that meant nothing and would mean everything, she had already put on her cardigan like armor. She wrote in a careful hand that one of the quilting ladies murmured over because it was pretty, and women are allowed to say, even at the edge of trouble, that a thing is pretty. She did not read what she wrote aloud. She slid it into the endpaper of a red Bible with a zipper, the kind campers use, and I laughed because God likes a man who appreciates a zipper. She handed the Bible to me under one condition, which she said out loud so it would stick to the walls.

“You will give it back to the church after,” she said, and I did not say after what.

The evidentiary hearing came hard and quick because Sloan had phrased his motion like something a decent man would want to hear while he still had a throat for questions. The courtroom filled with the usual: men in shirts that believe in starch, women with their dignity pinned where it was visible, a few kids whose teachers had called in a favor to turn law into civics for an hour. The warehouse men arranged themselves in the back like an upholstery sample of confidence. McCreedy’s lawyer wore a suit so correct it looked like it had voted already.

Sloan did the preliminaries with less theater than I like and more courage than I used to believe he owned. He marked the box, he called the thing a set of records, he asked the judge to mark the sleeve as an exhibit with a number that would look solemn on paper. He took the Bible from my hands with a look that took the measure of my religion and decided it did not matter. He unzipped and slid the two paragraphs out as if he were drawing breath. He did not look up as he read. When he reached the sentence where Elise had written, “I recognized the handwriting because I have been receiving church checks in that hand for eighteen years,” I saw the judge exhale and not want anyone to notice.

McCreedy’s lawyer asked questions that resize a person until they fit into the story he needs. He wondered whether Elise’s motives were pure, as if there were a test for that at the pharmacy next to the blood pressure cuff. He wondered whether she resented men who count money. He wondered whether she understood the term shell in the non-beach context. She did not answer from the stand because she was not on it. Her words answered in their good dress, and the hearing became a place where a woman’s neat script could make a man summarize himself.

The pharmacists came in whispered and left with their mouths braver. One man with a name badge that had lost its backing tape testified that he had been told to wait on a shipment because of “compliance,” and when asked to define compliance, he looked at the warehouse men and said, “Being obedient to the wrong person.” A woman with hair the color of a good sweet potato admitted she had altered a date field because she had been told to by someone who could not spell her name right. None of this was perfect. All of it was real.

Outside after, the air had the iron of a coming storm, or else we were all tasting the same fear in our mouths and mistaking it for weather. Sloan leaned against the wall not to look casual but because body and wall had finally stopped arguing. He had a smudge of red ink on his thumb where the tape had kissed him. He glanced down at it the way a man glances at proof of a game he had not intended to play and then nodded like he would, in fact, play it again.

“They will wiggle,” he said. “They will return a few cases to the pharmacies. They will blame a clerk. They will send their cousins to church. They will deny the shell is theirs. They will call Auxiliary an unfortunate coincidence and Logistics a misunderstanding of gratitude.”

“They will send more bears with their bellies cut,” I said, and he laughed without warmth this time, and then warmth arrived two beats late like a person running for the bus.

He went home to a child who was still small enough to climb onto knees and a piano small enough to sound like a toy even when someone serious touched it. Darla went back to do rounds without a badge, a woman who had taught herself a new way to carry what she wasn’t allowed to show. I went to Aimee’s desk because she had that look like she had spare courage in her drawer and was ready to loan it out. She gave me a sandwich, because she is a prophet of what you can accomplish when your blood sugar is not a pathetic idea, and then she brought me a stack of envelopes without return addresses because she has been paying attention.

The warehouse men weren’t idle while we played our pretty little legal music. Boone called to say a man had come by the feed store making conversation about the spring calves and had looked at the shelves with math eyes. The hospital sent a memo about pharmacy substitutions written in a tone administrators use when they want to sound like they care about your diet. Someone unscrewed the porch light at Elise’s house and then screwed it back in badly so it would flicker and make her think her power was sick. She put on her cardigan and fixed the bulb and texted me a picture of the screwdriver with the caption, I can mend my own light.

Joy’s numbers, because the universe likes us better when we think we deserve it, continued to behave. Her phone began to fill with things she wanted to remember later, and I have never been so honored to be sent such incompetently framed pictures. One was of her own forehead in a mirror, the fuzz reaching like a little joke that had decided to live. In the corner, taped to the glass, she had stuck a list that made my throat do something I associate with the last three minutes of a movie you didn’t think could earn your tears. It said: Ferris wheel at dusk, teach Earl to eat sushi, touch the river in winter, write a letter to the girl I was when I was twelve and put it in the freezer to make it last, learn a song without words.

Oakes stopped by with a bottle of terrible wine and a face that felt like it had just learned to be handsome. He had not sold the violin. He had met the woman with the perfume and she refused his offer of a check and accepted his offer of a walk around the block, which is how you know you are not a fool and have been for long enough that the universe owes you a little mercy. He played in my office while I pretended to sign something, because sometimes pretending you are at work is a better prayer than the ones we make on Sundays.

The bar complaint sat like a visitor who does not know how to excuse themselves gracefully. Mrs. Hale and I practiced what I would say. She told me to keep my adjectives folded small and my nouns lined up in their pews. She told me to press the temptation to grandstand like a wrinkle into a shirt with a hot iron and to pretend it was never there. She allowed me two metaphors and one memory, and took a yellow pencil and scored a line through the part of my draft that started with my mother and ended with grief, which felt like being corrected by a line of women in the quilts, and it was right.

In the middle of all this, Sloan sent me a recording late at night that he did not introduce. It was a minute and a half of a melody that felt like a walk around our block where someone has straightened their porch chairs and swept their step. It was stubbornly pretty, the way some men are pretty despite themselves, and it did the thing music sometimes does where it hangs a picture in your chest you didn’t give it permission to mount. I played it twice. On the third, I realized I was crying in the stupid ugly way that makes your jaw ache, and because I am trying to become the sort of person who tells the truth out loud in rooms where it will be used properly, I texted him, It made me hold my breath in the right way. He wrote back a single word and it wasn’t sorry. It was thanks.

The judge set the second hearing for a date that sat like a thumb in the middle of our week. Sloan would ask for the protective order again, this time with the red-taped sleeve and the pharmacists’ affidavits and the red Bible we would hand over with reverence, not because it was the law but because it belonged to a woman who had fixed her own lightbulb at midnight. Lorraine promised a person with a clipboard and a skeptical face at Saint Rose by Tuesday, and I told Darla I would bring her a dress with a good pocket and she told me to bring her instead a pen that doesn’t run and a thermos of soup.

“I dreamed last night I was stitching a vein,” Darla said in the corridor, voice barely above polite. “It was not violent. It was tidy. The body held still for me and the thread behaved and when I woke I understood I do not want to be praised for being brave anymore. I want to be paid in a sleep that does not take my pulse.”

“We’re building you a registry with a chair,” I said, like a man advertising a porch. “We cannot promise sleep. We can promise a place to sit.”

We walked together down the too-bright hall and nodded at a nurse whose hair had learned to make its own rules. The supply closet door was open a precise three inches, as if to announce absence. A foil package had been ripped too neatly to be accident and thrown away badly to be innocence. We have both learned how to read crime in the casual. Darla picked it up and smoothed it on her knee. Her fingers lingered on the edge where the serrations had been asked to do more than they were designed for. She slipped it into her pocket without ceremony, because sometimes the chain of custody begins with a woman who would rather heal than be tidy.

The site visit began in a conference room with lemon and mint in the water like Lorraine had predicted. A woman with a badge from the department sat with her shoulders arranged like a jazz rhythm and asked questions so clean they sounded like kindness. The board tried on their faces for responsibility and found that the fit did not flatter them. McCreedy called the Auxiliary a “temporary philanthropic vehicle,” and the woman with the badge wrote down those words like they were obliging little cattle she might lead into a pen later. Sloan did not attend because he understands better than I do when you need a man in a hallway and not at a table. I stayed because I wanted to see the expressions men make when the compliments they practiced for years fall to the carpet like paper you thought would behave.

At a break, the warehouse man with the good teeth approached me with a smile so clean it squeaked. He asked if I had enjoyed my sandwich and I told him the bread had been dry and the mustard cheap. He told me he admired my persistence and I told him I admired his wardrobe because it served the story he had chosen. He asked what story that was and I said the one where you tell yourself you are the kind of man who can stand in a room with dying people and argue for margins and not look down when your hands tremble. He looked down, and then he looked back up and said, “We can do high-minded all day, Barrett, but the numbers will ask for blood eventually.” I said, “Let’s give them ours.”

When I returned to the office, Aimee had put the sleeve in a box with a red thread tied around it because that is the sort of practical poetry she is capable of when she has eaten. She had also placed a small card on my desk with Elise’s name written in her best cursive and a phone number in a hand that looked like it had been taught by a teacher with a switch. Underneath, in Aimee’s print, were the words: She came by. Brought a pie. Told me to tell you the stitch held. P.S. It’s a chess pie. You like it better than you admit.

That night, because I am not quite the man I was, I took my mother’s quilt off the back of the chair and spread it over my bed. The room altered. It is a foolish thing to claim a blanket rearranges your lungs, but this one did, because quilts, like good filings and bad arguments, have a way of encouraging your body to remember its shape. My phone lit once on the nightstand and I let it. The city hummed its thin summer song. Down on Pecan, in the fellowship hall, women stitched and told the stories women tell when they do not intend any man to hear them, and a banner with a mended hem waited for a Sunday when it could boast without shame. Somewhere, a deputy flicked his cruiser lights for no reason except the human wish to light yourself up to prove you have some say in the dark.

In the morning, we would take the red-tied box and the red Bible and the affidavits to the courthouse and set them on the table where men with pens could not pretend they were not heavy. Lorraine would send an email with six words that could change a weather pattern and we would respond with sixteen that might hold. The pharmacy would receive a truck with a driver who had been told to pretend he got lost and he would not get lost. Joy would wake with her hair the exact right length to be mistaken for a choice. Sloan would whistle in the stairwell and forget, for an entire flight, that he was whistling. And I would put my hand on my chest where the small, stupid ache lives and feel it, like a seam you check not because you think it will fail but because you have learned that checking is a way to love the garment more.

Chapter 8

The morning of the second hearing, Meridian chose a light that made every paint chip look recent and every bruise more honest. A wind out of nowhere practiced its way down the courthouse lane and sent the magnolia petals spinning like pale coins too large to spend. I ironed a shirt that had never deserved an iron and told myself I was smoothing stubbornness into cotton, which is the kind of lie a man tells when he needs his sleeves to remember a better posture. Aimee pressed a thermos into my hand at the door and a packet of crackers into my pocket like I was being sent to first grade behind on my letters and ahead on appetite. Pil texted a blessing he’d stolen from a gospel song and signed it with a lightning bolt he pretends is a joke. On the steps, Sloan stood without his tie and with the new angle to his stance that said he had conceded his shoulders were for more than announcing his rank. He did not hum. He breathed like a man who had once monitored his breath for other men and had decided to keep it private until he needed the room to hear him.

Inside, the courtroom had the cold of a place that tries to keep feelings under glass. The judge’s clerk shuffled paper like a percussionist tasked with keeping time for a march that did not suit him. McCreedy’s lawyer sat with his portfolio open like a mouth lined with expensive teeth. The warehouse men arranged themselves behind him in that neat ridge a certain species of confidence leaves wherever it sleeps. Darla slid into a pew as if church had finally agreed to count her among the congregation. Lorraine wasn’t there, but her folder might as well have been; I felt its plain gravity at my back like a hand.

Sloan called it up like something you pull from a well and take time to admire for the sheen it managed to save. He laid our red-taped box on the evidence table with the square, deliberate tenderness of a man setting down a child after a long walk. The pharmacists’ affidavits went behind it, a fan of paper that held names we’d gotten good at saying in quiet rooms. He didn’t raise his voice. He didn’t point. He spoke about interference without law, a little like pneumonia without fever—the kind that hides until a person learns to listen to their own breath the way they learned to pretend not to. He used that word again, the one he had risked last time. Mercy. He said it without italics, which made it heavier.

McCreedy’s man did his professional frown and worried at the thread of intent like a cat that believes rugs were invented for it. He called the invoices unfortunate and the shell “merely an administrative convenience” and, for a wild moment, looked regretful, as if the phrase had cut his gums. The judge listened in that foxed way old men have when they understand a thing is true and are deciding if it is safe to admit it in public. He asked where the missing pallets had gone. He asked what policy had been invoked when the word compliance was put to work as a bouncer outside a door where patients waited in their good clothes with their hats in their hands. And then he did the thing we had been afraid to want him to do: he granted the order.

He didn’t grant us the cathedral some of us wanted. He gave us a steady chapel with a door that locked. Temporary. Narrow. Immediate. No vendor could withhold the antibiotic or its equivalents from any licensed pharmacy in the county absent an actual, documentable shortage or a federal recall. No substitution could be made for a hospital formulary item already in use without a patient-specific sign-off by a treating physician. All communications regarding acquisition of the relevant drugs were to be preserved and produced on seven days’ notice upon request of the department or the court. He read the words like nails. They went in straight. They made that nice sound when the last tap brings the head flush to the wood.

Something like breath moved through the room, and for once it wasn’t a hymn. The warehouse men didn’t flinch. They don’t. It isn’t how they were taught to make their faces. But one of them touched his cuff with two fingers as if remembering, too late, that fabric frays where it’s used most often. McCreedy stared as if we had sold him a dog and then told him it was a wolf. Darla closed her eyes and opened them and reached up to push a lock of hair behind her ear that had dared to escape and then let it fall where it wanted to, which is the kind of small rebellion you learn when your larger ones have been priced. Sloan said nothing. He took his copy of the order, folded it once, then placed it flat again like he hadn’t trusted his first instinct with paper in a long time and was beginning to.

Out on the steps, the heat had returned to its post like a guard who had taken a short, guilty nap. People touched my sleeve more than I am comfortable with, which is to say at all, and said my name in ways that made me wish I had been less available to names. A man I did not know put his hand on Sloan’s shoulder and squeezed once and left behind on the cotton a small wet mark his palm had made, and Sloan—who would once have looked down at that like a stain—let it sink in. Pil appeared from nowhere with a microphone he had no business having anywhere near a courtroom and asked me for a sentence that would fit between two weather reports, and I gave him “No one gets to lock the pantry when the house is on fire,” which is truly a ridiculous sentence but will play well at noon.

The order did what orders do. It behaved like a sudden stop sign on a road people had driven too fast down for years. There were near-collisions. There was cussing. There were some who slowed and looked around like men surprised to find the neighborhood had always been there and had gotten prettier while they drove with their heads down. A truck that had been circling turned its nose toward a pharmacy that had run out and, in a great show of compliance as performance, backed up too slowly to prove it had patience. We didn’t clap. We watched. Elise texted me a picture of the porch light glowing steady and a second of her hand with a line of red where she’d pricked herself on a pin. She had wrapped a Band-Aid tight enough to leave an oval, and beneath the photo she wrote, I mend fast.

That night, on the boardwalk that pretends the river likes to be civilized, Earl took Joy for sushi and managed, with a face like a man squaring up to a bull, to get a piece of tuna into his mouth without once looking betrayed. Joy took a picture of his eyes going wide like a child who has eaten snow for the first time and sent it to me with a caption that said, Look what the world can stand. Her fuzz had become a line, and the line had ideas. She kept touching it as if to remind it there would be scalp for it to visit if it would just act decent in public. Darla watched them from a polite distance like a woman hiding a smile in a chapel and texted me a list I didn’t deserve: the registry draft had come back with teeth intact, Lorraine had set a date for a first committee that would not call itself a committee, and the hospital had quietly returned her access to a few rooms without returning her badge, which is how institutions apologize when they want someone to be grateful and forgetful on schedule.

The bar set its little table near the back of my week and asked me to sit up straight and be small. Mrs. Hale arrived early with a tote bag that might well have been older than I am, and set out papers like plates. She touched my wrist once—not for tenderness, for calibration—and told me again which adjectives were the kind that get a man admired at supper and fired at breakfast. The panel wore the faces of people who had looked forward to noon and found themselves again at nine-thirty. I opened my mouth and closed it and then remembered to begin where Mrs. Hale had told me to: with verbs. I advised. I witnessed. I filed. I did not sell hope; I described a choice. If any of my sentences tried to sit on a lap they didn’t belong in, Mrs. Hale cleared her throat in a register that could cut paper. When they asked about the radio, I said that telling the truth is marketing’s older sister and the one who always stays to do dishes. When they asked if I profited, I told them I had learned to make my own sandwiches. When they asked about the line where I had said you can’t enjoin hope, I said I had been sentimental and meant I had been clumsy and then did not repeat it, which is a thing I am proud of because it is not my habit.

When they came back, their decision wore a suit that fit fine. Dismissed with admonition. It read like the note a careful teacher writes in the margin of a boy’s good essay where the paragraphs had gotten in an argument and had to be separated. Do not use the word miracle in any setting where a microphone may be present. Do not sign anything that smells like medicine. Do not use your mother as an argument unless directly asked. They did not put that last one in ink. They did not need to.

We celebrated by doing something ordinary badly. Pil dragged us to the fair out on the edge of town where the Ferris wheel lifts you exactly high enough to regret the view and then brings you back. The air smelled like grease and something whose sugar had been set on fire and forgiven. We stood in line like men who have not been allowed to stand in lines because other men have been calling their names out of them. Oakes showed up with his violin in a case he did not intend to open and opened it anyway because a child asked him to, and he found a corner where the speakers couldn’t insult him and played. He didn’t play anything anyone could hum after. He played the kind of tune that only exists in the ear where it is first heard and then refuses to travel. Sloan stood two yards away with his hands in his pockets and his head tilted and I watched him do the thing he had not been doing, which was to let his face be disorganized with pleasure. Joy reached the top of the wheel and shouted into the evening not a word, but a noise that felt like a hand slicing through water and finding it colder and better than expected. Earl held her ankle the way fathers hold ankles by muscle memory, and when they came down she held a prize she had not won, a blue bear with eyes too large for the head the way some mercies are too large for the days that carry them.

We had a week. I won’t call it peace, because peace is presumptuous. It was a stretch of days when the worst thing I had to contend with was a man at the hardware store wanting to tell me his cousin had been misdiagnosed in ‘98 and what we were doing now would have saved her then, and what did I propose to do about that particular time travel. The trucks came and did not pretend to be lost. The pharmacies on the dead-end streets got deliveries before the ones in the neighborhoods where the houses had cul-de-sacs like rings. The site visit produced a draft report that did not flinch at names, and the board responded with jargon that made me want to iron my tongue. Lorraine wrote me a four-line email that said as much with fewer nouns: We found a spine. Keep your nose clean. Bring us the next three patients. Do not confuse applause with progress.

The warehouse men did not forget how to curse a day. They switched tactics the way men do when a door closes softly and makes them wonder who paid for the hinge. Somebody dumped a stack of copy paper into the alley behind the office because our shredder had broken the week we started taking ourselves seriously and I hadn’t replaced it. Aimee went out with a broom and an expression she reserves for men wearing sandals with socks. She swept up the blank pages and said, without venting any heat she might have had a right to, that some folks don’t know the difference between mess and message. Someone let the air out of my tires and left four quarters on the hood like payment. I rolled the coins between my fingers and put them in a drawer where I keep kinds of currency that will not spend the way their faces suggest.

One night, the office learned a new kind of quiet. The old hat store hum is familiar to me now; the building and I share our small noises like people who have chosen to be married in a town that doesn’t know what to do with them. This quiet had weight. The lock didn’t protest. Whoever it was had practiced not making doorways take sides. I was sitting on the floor behind my desk because the chair had begun to feel like a perch and my knees needed to understand ground again. The man with the clean teeth wasn’t there. They didn’t send him for this sort of work. Two silhouettes. One held something that glinted. Not a weapon that argued. A blade that predicted. They went to the shelves like men looking for their own names and found nothing but files. A hand tugged at the red thread on the evidence box and then stopped when it met the neat seam of tape signed across by men who believe ink can hold. He looked at the other and made that small sound men make when they’ve been raised not to call out and something still presses on their throat. He set the box down as if it might snake. They left through the front because they wanted me to know they had known where I was and had chosen not to step on my neck. When I stood, my legs had that song you get after a run you didn’t train for and I pressed my palm on the red thread to make sure I could still feel the cordage through the cardboard. Aimee came from the back room holding the big stapler like a joke she was committed to and said, very calmly, that she would install a bell that made enough racket to please God.

If the town had any doubt about itself, the storm cleared it. A feeder band off a hurricane that didn’t know how to be generous came up the Pearl like an argument. The sky cast a green I associate only with the seconds before someone says something they cannot unsay. Power went out in clumps. Saint Rose’s generators decided they would like to demonstrate principles instead of performing their duty. Darla called me not to complain but because she has learned I am a man who will bring soup and a cooler and pretend either is a solution and then carry other things without a complaint I have not yet earned the right to make. Aimee took charge of flashlights like a field marshal pressed into service by boredom. Pil went on-air with a battery pack and told the town where the limbs were down and which grocery would sell you ice if you told the cashier your mother’s name without smiling. Sloan showed up at the hospital in a shirt he did not deserve to sweat through and lifted boxes until his breath got messy and then he lifted more because he understands now that the body insists on being present for justice and not just the voice.

In the dim, Joy’s room had the glow you get when the machines have decided not to perform for the audience and the human bodies do what they were taught by older human bodies. Earl fanned with a church program stolen from a funeral that had had better music than preaching. Joy made a joke about how much air costs when you get it by the ounce and then apologized to the nurse because she had made it all the way to a place past fear where humor becomes a skin you can live in. Darla moved like a woman reading a dance step that had been written for a floor that had warped overnight. The drug hung and dripped its careful repetitions. The antibiotic did its old-fashioned courage. We took turns pushing a cart back and forth between the pharmacy and the rooms whose lights were lying about their capacity to comfort.

At some hour that had forgotten which side of midnight to claim, we walked the hallway and saw a door ajar that never is. The supply closet had blown its cover again, or perhaps had chosen to. A box we did not need tipped forward and put its face on the floor. The thing we did need sat patient at the back like a shy child in a classroom that’s learned to reward noise. Something in me that had been on its half-knees for a month stood. We took what the order permitted and what the night demanded. We signed nothing. We made a note. We slid the packages into the coolers that had held other known mercies and kept them cold the way a town keeps the names of the dead without pretending it likes the chore. Dawn arrived like a man late to a meeting: breathless, wrong shirt, eager to convince us it had meant well all along.

When the lights came back, the town clapped at nothing in particular and wept where it had stashed its water. Sloan showed up at my office with a piano bench under his arm and I suppose that is a sentence only my life gets to hold. He set it down, and then, almost sheepish, pulled a cheap keyboard from a case and plugged it into an outlet as if he were a teenager who had gotten his first amplification without a parent present. He played me what he’d promised—the stubborn lovely—and I sat in my chair and realized my chair could be a pew if it wanted to and that I had been wrong to ask it to be only a place for taking calls that hurt. He didn’t ask me if it was any good because he had stopped needing my permission for his breath. When he finished, he said, without looking up, that he had given his notice.

He had done it quietly, because there are men in this world who do not owe an explosion, and he had written it in a hand that tried not to look like it was scripting a divorce and failed. He would stay through the month. He would see the motion through and he would take whatever punishment men like McCreedy thought they had earned the right to deliver by dint of owning floors we must walk across. He would then—here his voice went unsteady and correct itself—he would then work out of his house for a while, a room with a door and a little old wood that had learned where to creak and how to hush. His wife had agreed. His boy had clapped without knowing why. The office had blinked and smiled with only one side of its mouth. The town would do what towns do: pretend it had predicted it and take credit for encouraging him once by sitting attentively when he had said something handsome on a panel.

There is a moment in every new correctness where you look for permission and find, to your surprise, that the person you want to ask is asleep. Mrs. Hale, who never naps, allowed herself fifteen minutes in the chair in her back room and told the receptionist to wake her if someone came in with anything that smelled like a summary judgment. Lorraine sent a note saying she’d like to set a date for the pilot that could not be called a pilot and suggested that date be just far enough out to suggest responsibility and just near enough to imply urgency. The judge issued an order on a procurement email that read like a mother’s note left on a counter for a son who had taken the car and not called: Tell me where you were. Tell me who you were with. Tell me why you did not think I would wait up.

We took Joy to the river in the middle of the week because her list did not respect the calendar. It rained a little in sunshine, which is the only weather I believe in. She lay back on a blanket that had seen more grass than laundry and looked at the kind of blue that has something in it you can’t get your hands on. She dictated the letter to her twelve-year-old self because writing tired her. Dear Joy, you will think you are a joke for so long. You are not. You will think Earl is a fool and he is and he isn’t. You will think your hair is your personality and you will be wrong and then right. You will think the river is only summer and you will not know it freezes at the edges and the middle still moves. Fold this and put it near the peas. The brain likes to think in gardens. Her mother cried in that way women cry when other people might lay claim to the sadness if it runs, and wiped her eyes on the oranges scarf and then looked annoyed she had left marks on the fruit.

We got word from Buckley’s sisters that his numbers had tilted in a way that made them take out their good bowls. One sent a picture of him on the porch with the dog asleep on his foot like a weighted blanket, his cheeks fallen less and his eyes gone bright in a way that made me wonder if the drug doesn’t, in a small way, instruct the soul to behave. We sent back a recipe for a soup he wouldn’t make, because men like Buckley do not make soup. They ask the women whose hair they comb to make it and then insist on doing the dishes and chip a plate on purpose to announce they should never be allowed in the kitchen again. Darla drove out once at dusk with a trunk full of refrigerated stubbornness and all the words she had promised herself she would never say at a stranger’s table and said them anyway. She called me from the road, and I could hear the kind of dark where trees practice being taller, and said, very softly, that his sisters had wanted to pray and she had allowed them to and had put her hand on a shoulder the way women do when the prayer needs a body to land on.

The bears kept arriving. It had become a language, and I resented my fluency. The next had a stitch down the back as neat as a zipper and inside—a name tag from a charity gala where men had swapped jackets and stories without embarrassment. The next had no cut at all, just a pin in the paw with a note that said we are patient, and that one I gave to Joy after pulling the pin and she laughed and named it Patience because children, even when they have been in rooms where numbers decide everything, still enjoy turning a threat into a pet. Elise came by the office and fixed the loose thread on that one with such efficiency that I understood why men had once mistaken women like her for magicians and then punished them for it. She stayed for coffee and told Aimee she had been at the bank and seen a teller explain compound interest to a boy without condescension and had to sit down on the curb and breathe because it had been so beautiful. Then she stood and said she had pies in the car and would bring one only if we swore to bring the tin back with its dignity, and left without waiting for our oath because she knows us.

The AG’s office—which is to say, one man who cannot keep a secret and one woman who never will—issued a letter that said the word investigation without apology. Lorraine sent it to me with an attachment that contained more redactions than sense, and I wrote back a note I will keep for the rest of my life because of how few words it took to be correct. We were not wrong. She replied with a single period and I understood I had, at last, earned punctuation.

On a Saturday, when all decent upheavals ought to rest, Sloan asked me to meet him at the courthouse. He had gotten permission from the janitor, who understands the law of mop buckets and music and treats them both as liquid. In the rotunda, where once the echo had belonged only to men who liked to hear their jokes returned to them twice, Sloan set up his keyboard and Oakes stood like a man who had been waiting his whole life to be allowed to be this version of himself in a public building. They played together without speaking, two instruments remembering what a bridge is for, and people drifted in because the town knows when air changes. The deputy leaned in the door with his hat in his hand. Miss Laverne stood under the mural and cried with her mouth closed. A child lay down on the tile to feel the sound better because children know acoustics in their bones. I stood and let my face loosen where it wanted and I did not apologize for it then or later. Between songs, Sloan said, like a man who had discovered an extra room in his own house, that he had taken a lease on the old hat repair shop two doors down from me and would be teaching a few piano students on weekdays and some men who needed to learn what their wrists were for on Saturdays. He looked afraid and certain in the precise amounts needed to be forgiven in advance.

That night, I slept under my mother’s quilt with the window open and the fan doing its clicking metronome. The street sounded like a town that had worked and washed and gone to bed without finishing every task and forgiven itself for it. My phone sat face down like a respectful witness. When I woke, I had dreamed nothing sententious and felt for the cut at the crease of my thumb and found that it had knitted without me watching. Downstairs, a letter waited from Lorraine with a letterhead that still surprises me because I am not used to being written to by the state without dread. She wanted Darla in Jackson on Monday to sit in a room where a whiteboard would pretend to contain the choices of a whole body, and she wanted me to come, too, only to carry a folder and not to speak unless someone needed a sentence taken apart and sewn back together.

We dressed like we were going to a funeral that had been postponed and went to sit in a room where people had brought their own pens and had decided that day would obey them. Carrow sat quietly and earned the attention of a woman whose attention had been late to waking. A statistician with a haircut that could have been used to cut paper wrote numbers in a way that made the air relax because the slash of a seven had not been enlisted to lie. Darla spoke like water, steady and insistent and bending around some rocks. I spoke once and made a joke that did its work and then shut up, which is the kind of victorious maturity that ought to win a man a prize he does not need. A schedule went up under the kind of heading men like me can die under—Pilot, North District, Phase One—and we all pretended not to see the irony and wrote names under months like children at the chalkboard pretending school is permanent.

Driving home, the fields had that September lie where they look done when they are not. The magnolias had traded their lacquer for dust, and the freight train made a sound like grease, and Meridian did that thing where it made itself smaller to fit into your chest and then larger just to prove it could. A text from Buckley’s sisters came through saying he had slept a whole night and dreamed about a fence his daddy had built wrong and we all knew what that meant: the body had decided, briefly, to continue. Joy sent a photo of the freezer with a letter tucked behind the peas and a smile that did not run from its own face. Aimee had bought a new shredder and had put a ribbon around it and told the office it should greet it with respect. Elise had baked, which meant we had won something temporary and beautiful.

I pulled into my drive and saw, at the base of the pecan, a box with no return address and a ribbon that had cost someone more than decency dictates. Inside, a bear with no seam cut and no pin and no card. Around its belly, a small belt of measuring tape like the kind my mother used to snap when she wanted my shoulders to behave. The tape had numbers that didn’t line up, and for a second my throat did that closing thing grief and laughter use in common. I took the tape off, coiled it, and put it in the drawer where I keep other instruments no one has asked me to play. The bear went on the chair beneath the quilt and did its small, silly work of making the room remember it could hold softness and peril in adjacent chairs without one swallowing the other.

I was making coffee I didn’t need when the phone rang with the sound I have learned to call urgent without letting it claim my whole face. Lorraine’s voice had that thread of iron she keeps coiled for use, and she said the words any town like ours has been waiting to have to hear and not hear. The AG’s office had served warrants. Someone had bent, and not the person whose bending would have been satisfying. A procurement manager had confessed before she had been asked to. A warehouse bookkeeper had discovered his god. Auxiliary had dissolved itself overnight like sugar in hot water and left behind the aftertaste of cheap mint. There would be charges. There would be statements. There would be Sunday. She said, as if we were talking about rain, that we should expect a parade and an ambush and that sometimes in life they are the same block.

I stood with the phone to my ear and watched the steam write its ceremony in the kitchen air and then vanish, and I thought of the seam in the courthouse rotunda where two old stones meet and how, if you run your finger along it, you can feel the line but it will not cut you. I thought of Sloan, who would be learning a new quiet in his house, and of Darla, who would be buying a dress with pockets not because of the meeting but because she had remembered what to put in them. I thought of Joy, who would be making a list of things you can do with hair two inches long that you cannot do with hair you hide inside a scarf, and of Earl, who would say sushi now as if it were his idea. I thought of Elise, who would be mending the hem of a banner we would one day walk beneath without forgetting who held the needle while the town debated its font.

And I thought of my mother, which is to say I thought of the way she would squint at the stitch and nod and then, because she knew a seam alone is not a garment, pick up the other piece and ask me to hold the far edge while she made a join that could stand a season.

Chapter 10

Sunday arrived pretending to be kind. The sky had that pale, freshly laundered look that makes even bad siding on old houses look intentional. Pecan leaves held still like a congregation caught mid-breath. I ironed a shirt I had no business ironing because the cloth didn’t deserve heat and care that early in the week, but some mornings you need to do something with a hot plate and a stubborn crease to make the rest of the day believe you can finish it. My mother’s quilt looked restful on the chair, sage and russet and three squares that never quite match because she’d run out of one print and refused to pretend the replacement had always been the plan. When the coffee went from impatient steam to something like a ceremony, my phone buzzed with messages that made a small, nervous music on the counter. Aimee: wear a jacket with inside pockets and do not say you’ll give it to me later because you won’t. Pil: parade starts at two, I’ve got a spot by the bandstand, keep your metaphors to what fits between a drumroll and a sponsor mention. Sloan: the janitor is a saint; if the weather holds I’ll set up in the rotunda after the thing with the floats. Lorraine: press conference noon; state will speak like a grown-up; bring one copy of everything that makes you feel taller.

Meridian’s Founders’ Day parade has always been more confession than celebration. We line up our tractors not because we need to but because we like to see if the paint still shines; we put our middle schoolers in matching T-shirts so they can practice the synchronized embarrassment that will take them into high school; the churches build floats with themes that would make you blush if you had time to think about where the glue came from. The warehouse men sponsor the water table, and the tablecloth always has their logo repeating like a wallpaper pattern in a room you don’t get to sit down in. This year there was a banner stitched by the quilting circle that had been mended so well you wouldn’t have seen the seam unless a woman raised you right pointed it out. Miss Laverne stood under it in a shirt with more starch than a principled apology and gave orders with a chin you could have measured your courage against.

Joy wore a headband no one would accuse of being practical. The fuzz had declared itself hair sometime between Friday morning and Saturday night, and she had decided, with that meticulous mercy she gives herself on good days, to let it be seen and not just touched by hands that ask permission. Darla wore a dress with pockets because I had promised to bring her a pen that doesn’t run and soup; she had found the pockets and put her hands in like a woman choosing not to be argued with. Earl had folded the parade route map and placed it inside his back pocket and then pulled it out and put it back in until the crease remembered where it belonged. Elise stood near the church float with a pair of scissors in her cardigan pocket and a look that said if anybody pulled a thread they hadn’t earned, she knew how to cut a man’s metaphor in half.

Before the parade, the courthouse steps filled with the kind of crowd that shows up for free water and breaks for justice when it’s offered. Lorraine didn’t take the mic; that’s not her show. The state’s lawyer with the neat part and the low voice stood with a poster-board of bullet points that had never felt more like ammunition and said, without ceremony, that Auxiliary Logistics had been “dissolved under scrutiny,” that sealed boxes had become open questions, that a procurement manager had entered a plea to something with the kind of consonants people pretend not to hear, and that donors do not cure scarcity by inventing it. She kept the nouns close together and let the verbs do their work. When she finished, no one clapped. Meridian doesn’t applaud announcements the way cities do. We let the words sit and see if they start to smell like truth when the day warms them a little.

The ambush, of course, came with a smile. It always does, because men who train their faces to sell you a refrigerator in winter do not unlearn the softness that keeps you from slamming the door. He wore a volunteer sash that let him approach any body with a clipboard and a bottle of water. He called me Barry like we were cousins and handed me a manila folder with a label in a font I know too well to trust. The other hand held an identical folder for Darla. “Just so you’re informed,” he said, and glanced toward the photographers who had discovered the angle of a lawsuit looks prettier than a promise when you’re trying to make a front page behave. I didn’t look at the camera, because my mother would have scolded me with her eyebrows and told me to read before I performed.

The complaint called us wicked names in courteous language. Defamation and interference and a fanciful paragraph about “misappropriation of institutional goodwill” that made me want to iron the strip of paper it was printed on until the letters begged for mercy and promised to behave. They had cut Joy’s parents into the suit like a seam you add last minute when you realize the garment won’t hang; they wore the words “conspiracy of public confusion” and I felt Earl’s breath go wrong even through three feet of air. He is a man who pretends not to care what the town says about him until the town says it loud enough for the girls to hear. Darla didn’t flinch; she took the pages with the same hand she uses to hold a vein steady and slid them into the pocket I’d admired. “We have a parade,” she said to the volunteer. “You have a conscience. Let’s see which of us can find what we need first.”

When I looked up, Sloan was already moving toward the courthouse. He has cultivated a stillness lately, but on certain days he remembers motion is permissible for men who intend to be decent. He didn’t touch my arm and I didn’t need him to. In the rotunda, he set his keyboard where men used to set petitions and played the thing he refuses to title that makes my chest decide to behave for a full two minutes. People drifted from floats and water stations and the edges of their own intentions and let the sound remind their faces what they would like to believe they look like. The warehouse men stood under the second-floor rail the way owls pretend to be part of architecture. One adjusted his cuff again; one checked his phone like phones absolve us from having to check our hearts.

Lorraine’s press conference did what it owed. It gave people a sentence to say at lunch that does not make them sound like they slept through the morning. “The state secured warrants” works in almost any conversation if you season it with a good side-eye. It also let the hospital rehearse a statement in which they used the phrase “isolated administrative lapses” and “unforeseen downstream effects” and a paragraph about “the importance of patient-centered care” that would have sat better if it hadn’t been announced by a man whose pencil line hair and clean fingertips made me think of how careful he must be not to get real ink on anything. Pil took to the airwaves with that delighted sobriety he reserves for days when he gets to say the word accountability without having to use the words allegedly and forthcoming. He called me live and asked for a sentence he could fit before the citrus farm ad, and I said, “We learned to carry a file box like a baby and it paid off,” and he groaned and said he would edit my metaphors in post and keep the baby.

The parade went on because towns do not cancel tradition for truth; they carry both and get shin splints. The high school band tried to march in a straight line down a street that refuses to be honest about its width. The Shriners did their little car ballet that shapes a figure eight so pretty you forget half the drivers are accountants who cry at the price of wood. A float sponsored by a chain pharmacy had an oversized pill bottle painted with a smile that would have unsettled me on any other day; today it felt like a fairytale eaten by an after-school special. The church banner sailed past with its mended hem daring any camera to zoom and find the stitch. Elise walked beside it holding a stick with the calm of a woman who has been asked to steady men all her life and has chosen, finally, to let the fabric do some of its own work.

The ambush’s second act stepped out of a white tent with pastries. A boy in a polo with a logo that had not existed last week offered Joy’s mother a check the way you offer a woman a chair when she isn’t sure if she’s allowed to sit. “A family assistance gift,” he said, and pretended not to notice the photographers doing their good-citizen crouch. The number was too round to be nice. Darla looked at the paper like it was a stain on a tablecloth she had just laundered. Earl’s mouth flattened and his hand went toward his back pocket and then stopped because the map was there and maps are for directions, not for fists.

“You can refuse money without refusing people,” Darla said to nobody in particular and everybody in earshot. She is better than I am at saying the sentence you want the town to repeat instead of the one it will. Joy took the check, folded it in half without looking at the amount, handed it to her mother, and said, with the easy teenage cruelty that saves lives when it is correctly applied, “You can mail them a thank-you from the future when I’m done needing it.” Her mother smiled the tight smile of a woman who will accept a kind that isn’t clean only to change it into clean later in the kitchen with a pair of scissors and a stamp and the good pen.

I took Darla’s stack of pages into the shade and skimmed while the marching girls did a routine that made my knees hurt in sympathy. The suit had been filed in a county friendlier to glossy folders than to quilts. It was signed by a firm from a city that sells glass for a living. It wanted to enjoin our tongues and wrists and computers and the path from the pharmacy loading bay to the street. It wanted to erase Elise with a red pen and to put Lorraine in a box labeled Overstep. It named Oakes because they needed a musician to make the story less about women who sew. Mrs. Hale, who somehow knows when the air goes sour in any building that keeps paper, texted that she was in her office with a pot of tea and two kinds of response already half-written, and to bring my face and not my feelings.

By the time the parade thinned into children dragging plastic sacks with five peppermints and a pocket handful of heat, the ambush had softened into neighborliness again. Men who had shouted my name in the morning nodded as if seeing me in public had made me less likely to be an idea they disagreed with. Sloan finished his impromptu concert without bowing and without begging the crowd for anything more than air. He stayed seated for a long moment, hands on his thighs, eyes on the keyboard like a man reading a letter he knows he will keep in the same drawer as his father’s watch.
